questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic due to a fever for the last 5 days. The patient also noticed a decrease in urine output. Five years ago the patient developed end-stage renal disease secondary to diabetes mellitus and subsequently underwent kidney transplantation 3 months ago. Current medications include insulin glargine and tacrolimus. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued, and there is tenderness to palpation at the site of the transplant. A biopsy from the transplanted kidney shows dense lymphocytic infiltrate. The patient is started on treatment with mycophenolate mofetil. Which of the following medications has a similar enzyme target to that of mycophenolate mofetil?
questions.solution:
This patient is currently experiencing acute graft rejection, which is characterized by dense lymphocytic infiltration of the graft. It often presents with fever and oliguria. Acute graft rejection can be reversed with the use of potent immunosuppressants; this includes steroids or mycophenolate mofetil.  

Mycophenolate mofetil is an immunosuppressant that can be used to protect against (or reverse) organ transplant rejection. It inhibits purine synthesis by inhibiting inosine-5'-monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH), the rate-limiting enzyme in de novo purine synthesis. It preferentially targets this enzyme in B- and T-lymphocytes, the main cells responsible for acute and chronic graft rejection. In addition, it can be used against a wide range of autoimmune disorders such as lupus nephritis, and autoimmune hepatitis.   

One of the advantages of mycophenolate mofetil is that it is less likely to cause nephrotoxicity and neurotoxicity than calcineurin inhibitors. However, it is associated with significant GI symptoms, and less commonly hypertension, hyperglycemia, and even pancytopenia.  

IMPDH is also the target of ribavirin, an antiviral agent used in the treatment of hepatitis C virus and respiratory syncytial virus. By inhibiting IMPDH, ribavirin prevents viral RNA from being synthesized, inhibiting viral replication.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ribavirin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pyrimethamine:
Incorrect: Pyrimethamine is an antiparasitic drug that is used in the treatment of toxoplasmosis. It works similarly to methotrexate by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, thereby reducing the generation of tetrahydrofolate.
❌ Trimethoprim:
Incorrect: Trimethoprim is an antibacterial drug that is usually given with sulfamethoxazole. Like pyrimethamine and methotrexate, the target of trimethoprim is dihydrofolate reductase.
❌ Cyclosporine:
Incorrect: Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant used to prevent organ transplant rejection. Cyclosporine, like tacrolimus, is a calcineurin inhibitor that prevents transcription of immune cytokines (e.g. interleukin-2), halting the proliferation and differentiation of the immune cells.
❌ Leflunomide:
Incorrect: Leflunomide is an immunosuppressant used to treat autoimmune disorders. It inhibits the synthesis of pyrimidines by inhibiting dihydroorotate dehydrogenase, the rate-limiting enzyme in de novo pyrimidine synthesis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the nephrology clinic to discuss renal transplantation. Past medical history is significant for Alport syndrome, which led to end-stage renal disease 2 years ago. Currently, the patient undergoes hemodialysis three times per week. The father of the patient decides to donate his kidney to the patient and a kidney transplantation is scheduled. In order to prevent acute rejection, the patient will be given a monoclonal antibody that prevents T cell activation and proliferation. Which of the following is the primary target of this monoclonal antibody?
questions.solution:
This patient developed end-stage renal disease due to Alport syndrome, one of the causes of chronic kidney disease in the pediatric population. Alport syndrome is primarily an X-linked genetic disorder that is caused by a mutation in type IV collagen (from the COL4 gene). It is characterized by ocular abnormalities (e.g. retinopathy), hearing loss, progressive glomerulonephritis, and chronic kidney disease. Renal transplantation is indicated in pediatric end-stage renal disease.  

Immunosuppressants are used post-transplant in order to prevent rejection and graft failure.  Basiliximab is a monoclonal antibody directed at the interleukin-2 receptor (IL-2R). It is used in renal transplantation to prevent acute rejection. Basiliximab binds to the alpha-subunit of IL-2R, blocking it, preventing its activation. This leads to suppression of IL-2-mediated T cell activation and proliferation, reducing alloantigen recognition and graft rejection.   

Side effects of IL-2R monoclonal antibodies are usually mild and well-tolerated. They may cause hypertension, peripheral edema, and in rare cases tremors.  

Option Analysis

✅ Interleukin-2 receptor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ CD20:
Incorrect: Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody that binds specifically to CD20 found on B lymphocytes. Rituximab is used to treat B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphomas and certain autoimmune or vasculitis conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, granulomatosis with polyangiitis).
❌ Epidermal growth factor receptor:
Incorrect: Cetuximab is a monoclonal antibody against epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR). It is used in the treatment of colorectal cancer and head and neck cancer.
❌ Immunoglobulin E :
Incorrect: Omalizumab is an anti-IgE monoclonal antibody that is used in the treatment of severe uncontrolled asthma with high IgE levels.
❌ Cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-associated protein 4:
Incorrect: Cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-associated protein 4 (CTLA-4) is an inhibitory molecule that downregulates the T-cell response and helps prevent autoimmunity. Ipilimumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to and blocks CTLA-4, potentiating and prolonging T-cell activation and enhancing the cytotoxic T-cells effect on tumor recognition and destruction.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man is referred to the nephrology clinic after serum creatinine was found to be elevated. The patient underwent a renal transplantation one month ago and is currently not experiencing any symptoms. The patient developed end-stage renal disease 5 years ago after a severe acute kidney injury from septic shock. The patient underwent three times weekly hemodialysis until receiving a kidney donation from a family member. Current medications include cyclosporine and sirolimus. The patient does not use tobacco or drink alcohol. Temperature is 37.1C (98.78F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 145/89 mmHg. Select laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of elevated serum creatinine in this patient?

 Complete Blood Count (CBC)
 Hemoglobin  12.7 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  45% 
 Leukocyte count  2500/mm3 
 Platelet count  200,000/mm3 
 Complete Metabolic Panel (CMP)
 Sodium  138 mEg/L 
 Potassium  4.3 mEq/L 
 Calcium  8.3 mg/dL 
 Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN)  55 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  2.2 mg/dL 
 Urinalysis
 Protein  Negative 
 Glucose  Negative 
 Blood  Negative 
 Casts  Few hyaline 
 Leukocyte esterase  Negative 
 Nitrites  Negative
questions.solution:
This patient has developed an elevation in serum creatinine after kidney transplantation. Absence of significant findings on urinalysis and the elevated BUN/creatinine ratio suggests a prerenal cause. This is most likely due to afferent arteriolar vasoconstriction caused by cyclosporine.  

Cyclosporine is a calcineurin inhibitor that is used frequently to prevent transplant rejection and can also be used in treatment of certain autoimmune disorders. Normally, after T-cells are exposed to an antigen, calcineurin gets activated and dephosphorylates a transcription factor known as the Nuclear Factor of Activated T cells (NFAT). NFAT then translocates to the nucleus and induces transcription of immune mediator cytokines; most importantly interleukin-2 (IL-2). IL-2 provides the signal needed for T-cell activation and proliferation. Cyclosporine inhibits the transcription of IL-2 by inhibiting calcineurin, thereby halting T cell proliferation and protecting the transplanted organ from T cell-mediated injury.    

One of the major limitations of cyclosporine use is its severe nephrotoxic effects. Acute nephrotoxicity is related to afferent arteriolar vasoconstriction, which decreases the glomerular filtration rate, renal plasma flow, and creatinine clearance. As there is no intrinsic kidney injury, the urinalysis is usually bland. This is usually reversible with cyclosporine dose reduction. Long-term use can cause chronic nephrotoxicity marked by tubulointerstitial fibrosis, which is usually irreversible. Cyclosporine can also cause hypertension, gingival hyperplasia, hirsutism, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.  



Option Analysis

✅ Cyclosporine side effect:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Sirolimus side effect:
Incorrect: Sirolimus is an immunosuppressant that is frequently used in combination with cyclosporine as a prophylaxis for transplant rejection. However, unlike calcineurin inhibitors, sirolimus is not known to have any nephrotoxic effects.
❌ Acute kidney transplant rejection:
Incorrect:  Acute graft rejection usually occurs in the first 6 months post-transplant. It can be asymptomatic or the patient may have fever, malaise, oliguria and graft tenderness. Urinalysis however usually shows pyuria and proteinuria.
❌ Chronic transplant rejection:
Incorrect: Chronic kidney transplant rejection happens after the first year of transplant and manifests with gradually declining kidney function, worsening hypertension, and increasing proteinuria on urinalysis.
❌ BK virus reactivation:
Incorrect: BK polyoma virus is a DNA virus that infects renal tubules in many people and remains quiescent. It can get reactivated in transplanted kidneys and may lead to graft failure. Reactivation is usually asymptomatic and is detected as an increase in serum creatinine. However, urinalysis usually shows pyuria, hematuria, and tubular casts.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the nephrology clinic for a follow-up appointment. The patient previously had end-stage renal disease secondary to adult polycystic kidney disease and underwent kidney transplantation 5 years ago. The patient is currently on maintenance treatment with an immunosuppressant that inhibits the activation of T cells by inhibiting intracellular response to cytokines. Which of the following is a known side effect of this immunosuppressant?
questions.solution:
This patient previously underwent kidney transplantation and in order to prevent organ rejection was given sirolimus. Sirolimus is an immunosuppressant frequently used in renal transplant patients that works by inhibiting the proliferation of lymphocytes in response to cytokines.    

When sirolimus enters T cells, it binds to a protein called FK-binding protein (FKBP) and inhibits mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin). In IL-2-activated cells, mTOR becomes activated and promotes cellular growth and proliferation. Therefore, inhibiting mTOR sirolimus blocks the proliferation of immune cells in response to cytokines.  

Sirolimus is specifically indicated in renal transplantation to prevent rejection. It is frequently used in combination with cyclosporine due to synergistic immunosuppressive effects. Additionally, sirolimus is used in cardiac stents as a drug-eluting agent to prevent intimal proliferation and restenosis from induced inflammatory response.

Unlike calcineurin inhibitors, sirolimus is not nephrotoxic. However, sirolimus can lead to severe bone marrow suppression and pancytopenia. Hyperglycemia and hyperlipidemia are other known side effects of sirolimus.



Option Analysis

❌ Nephrotoxicity:
Incorrect: Sirolimus inhibits the immune cells’ response to cytokines. One of the major advantages of sirolimus is the lack of nephrotoxic effects, which are commonly associated with calcineurin inhibitors (e.g., tacrolimus, and cyclosporine). Calcineurin inhibitors impair the synthesis of (not response to) cytokines.
✅ Pancytopenia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Neurotoxicity:
Incorrect: Neurotoxicity is mainly associated with the use of tacrolimus, although it can be less commonly seen in cyclosporine. Both tacrolimus and cyclosporine are calcineurin inhibitors that decrease the synthesis of cytokines. Sirolimus is not associated with neurotoxicity.
❌ Gingival hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Gingival hyperplasia is a known side effect of cyclosporine. It is not seen in patients taking sirolimus. 
❌ Macrocytosis:
Incorrect: Macrocytosis is seen with certain drugs like hydroxyurea and methotrexate. However, sirolimus is not known to cause macrocytosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician’s office for evaluation of a rash under her breasts. She first noticed the rash two days ago while bathing. The patient reports recurrent rashes of similar appearance affecting her face and limbs since the age of two. She was recently treated for oral thrush at a local clinic. Past medical history is significant for hypothyroidism managed with levothyroxine. Family history is significant for a brother who experienced similar cutaneous symptoms and died of fulminant hepatitis at the age of six. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates red-brown, beefy, homogenous patches under the breasts and massive erythematous-desquamating dermatosis involving the face, limbs and nails. Genital examination shows multiple labial fissures. Intraepidermal injection of Candida antigens yields no reactogenicity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a red-brown, beefy rash under the breasts, with a history of recurrent similar rashes affecting her face and limbs. In addition, her history demonstrates a recent treatment for oral thrush and absent cutaneous reaction to Candida antigens, which is suggestive of chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis (CMCC).

CMCC refers to a heterogeneous syndrome characterized by persistent noninvasive Candida albicans infections of skin, nails and mucous membranes.  Clinically, these rashes are characterized as erythematous, scaly cutaneous plaques in intertriginous areas, mucosae and nails. Besides the oral cavity, other mucosal surfaces including esophageal, genital and laryngeal mucosa may also be involved.

CMCC results from impaired T-cell mediated immunity towards Candida species. It can be caused by a number of genetic defects, but the classic form results from autoimmune regulator (AIRE) deficiency. In addition to chronic non invasive candidiasis, affected patients can also manifest with autoimmune polyendocrinopathy (hypoparathyroidism, hypothyroidism, adrenal insufficiency, and skin dystrophy). Diagnosis is based upon clinical features, identifying disease-causing mutations, and absence of reactogenicity with injection of candida antigens.  

Option Analysis

❌ Severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome:
Incorrect: Although severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome can present with chronic candidal infections (oral thrush), affected patients typically present in infancy with failure to thrive as well as chronic diarrhea, bacterial, viral, or protozoal infections.
✅ Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyperimmunoglobulin E syndrome:
Incorrect: Although hyperimmunoglobulin E syndrome can manifest with recurrent mucocutaneous candida infections, other symptoms such as bacterial abscesses and retained primary teeth are present.
❌ Medication side effect:
Incorrect: This patient is receiving treatment with levothyroxine for hypothyroidism and was most likely treated with an antifungal agent for oral thrush. None of these medications predispose to recurrent candida skin infections.
❌ Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome:
Incorrect: Although acquired immunodeficiency syndrome can present with mucocutaneous candidiasis, untreated infections usually become invasive with systemic spread. Moreover, in the absence of risk factors and other clinical manifestations (fever, lymphadenopathy, sore throat, rash, myalgia/arthralgia, and headache), it is an unlikely diagnosis.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to her primary care physician's office for evaluation of unsteady gait. The parent states the patient’s gait has become “wobbly,” and she has been experiencing recurrent falls. The parent also reports it is difficult to understand her speech. Her development was normal until the age of two years, when she started developing these symptoms. Past medical history is significant for recurrent respiratory tract infections. Family history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates numerous superficial nests of distended blanchable capillaries on sun-exposed areas. The patient is unable to coordinate head and eye movements when shifting gaze. This patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient who presents with an unsteady gait, abnormal eye movements, recurrent respiratory infections and superficial nests of blanching distended capillaries is most likely suffering from ataxia telangiectasia (AT). Patients with AT are at an increased risk of developing lymphoma and leukemia.

AT is an autosomal recessive disorder secondary to a mutation in the ataxia telangiectasia mutated (ATM) gene. This gene encodes a protein kinase that normally phosphorylates tumor suppressor protein p53 to repair double-stranded breaks in the DNA. As such, it is important in the development and reproduction of immune cells--especially T lymphocytes.



Defects in the ATM gene ultimately manifest in a failure to detect DNA damage, an inability to halt progression of the cell cycle, and accumulation of gene mutations.




Affected patients present in the first years of life with the characteristic triad of cerebellar ataxia (due to cerebellar atrophy), increased risk of sinopulmonary infections and telangiectasias (numerous superficial blanching nests of distended capillaries on sun-exposed areas). This disease predisposes individuals to hematologic malignancies (lymphoma and leukemia) and immunodeficiency; primarily manifesting as IgA deficiency. Due to the defect in DNA repair, affected patients are hypersensitive to radiation, which can lead to chromosomal breaks.



The diagnosis of AT is based on clinical features in conjunction with mutations in the ATM gene detected via genetic testing. Laboratory analysis will typically demonstrate a low level of serum immunoglobulins and a high level of alpha-fetoprotein.   

Option Analysis

❌ Hypocalcemia:
Incorrect: Hypocalcemia can occur as a complication of DiGeorge syndrome, which presents with pure T cell deficiency (infections), abnormal facies, and hypocalcemia (due to parathyroid hypoplasia). Neurologic abnormalities like ataxia are atypical.
✅ Lymphoma and leukemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Non Invasive Candida infections:
Incorrect: Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis is characterized by persistent noninvasive Candida albicans infection of the skin, nails and mucous membranes. It results from impaired T cell mediated immunity against Candida due to AIRE deficiency. Neurologic abnormalities like ataxia, respiratory infections, and superficial dilated blood vessels are atypical of this condition.
❌ Recurrent infection with Neisseria sp.:
Incorrect: Terminal complement deficiency (deficiency of complements C5-C9 ) a component of membrane attack complex, can cause recurrent infections with Neisseria sp. Aside from pulmonary involvement, other infections are uncommon in patients with ataxia telangiectasia.
❌ Hematochezia:
Incorrect: Hematochezia can occur as a complication of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome secondary to thrombocytopenia. In addition to bacterial infections and thrombocytopenia, eczema is also commonly observed in these patients. Superficial blanching nests of distended capillaries are atypical.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man comes to his primary care physicians office for evaluation of chronic diarrhea and associated nausea and bloating. He visited a local health care clinic and was prescribed a course of antibiotics, without relief of symptoms. Past medical history is significant for asthma, eczema and an anaphylactic reaction to blood transfusion two years ago. Family history is noncontributory. He does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.2 C (99.0 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Microscopic examination of his stool for ova and parasites is shown.



Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following pathophysiologic findings is most strongly associated with this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of recurrent diarrhea, atopy (eczema and asthma) and anaphylaxis during blood transfusions. The presence of pear-shaped organisms with multiple flagella is indicative of Giardia lamblia. Together, these findings are suggestive of selective IgA deficiency, the most common primary immune deficiency.

IgA is produced when B cells are stimulated by interleukin- 5 (IL-5) or transforming growth factor- β, with subsequent class switching occurring in mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue. From here, IgA is secreted into the saliva, sweat, or intestines.




In IgA deficiency, both secretory and serum IgA levels are low. The exact mechanism underlying this deficiency is not well-established; however, it is thought to result from a cytokine defect in B cells or T cells. Multiple members of the same family are commonly affected, implicating a genetic component.




Most individuals with selective IgA deficiency are asymptomatic, although some may have recurrent sinopulmonary infections (e.g. sinusitis) or gastrointestinal infections (Giardia lamblia). There is also an increased frequency of atopy, as well as autoimmune diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis and SLE), and increased risk of some malignancies (e.g. gastric and colon cancer). Some patients with severe IgA deficiency develop IgE antibodies against IgA, manifesting in fatal anaphylactic reactions.



Diagnosis is based on low or undetectable levels of serum IgA (due to the failure of B-cells to differentiate into IgA secreting plasma cells) and normal levels of other immunoglobulins (IgM, IgG and IgE). There is no effective treatment for selective IgA deficiency. Patients with severe deficiency should wear a medical alert bracelet, and if a blood transfusion is necessary, washed erythrocytes should be administered. 

Option Analysis

❌ Eosinophil-mediated cytotoxicity:
Incorrect: Eosinophils are important for defense against intestinal helminthic infections. They are not an essential component for defense against Giardia.
❌ Complement deficiency:
Incorrect: Early complement deficiencies are associated with infections with encapsulated species, while Neisseria gonorrhoeae or meningitidis infection is seen with late complement (C5–C9) deficiencies.
✅ Selective immunoglobulin deficiency:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ T-cell dysfunction:
Incorrect: An example of pure T-cell dysfunction is DiGeorge syndrome (thymic hypoplasia). Affected patients have congenital absence of thymus and parathyroid glands secondary to maldevelopment of third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. Absence of T-cells causes bacterial and viral infections, while absence of the parathyroid gland causes hypocalcemia.
❌ Defect of NADPH oxidase:
Incorrect: A defect of NADPH oxidase results in decreased production of reactive oxygen species and respiratory burst. Affected patients are susceptible to infections with catalase positive organisms (e.g. Staphylococcus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa).

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to his primary pediatrician for evaluation of recurrent infections. The parents report the patient had two episodes of severe pneumonia, an episode of otitis media, and herpes labialis in the past nine months. He was born at 38 weeks gestation to a 28-year-old otherwise healthy woman. He eats and drinks normally and has achieved the normal developmental milestones. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a well-developed and well-nourished child with fair complexion. He has eczema on his cheeks and trunk as well as petechiae on the bilateral lower extremities. Laboratory evaluation reveals a leukocyte count of 8,000/mm3 and a platelet count of 70,000/mm3. Flow cytometry of peripheral lymphocytes reveal absence of the WAS protein. Which of the following immunologic processes is most likely affected given this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent infections, eczema, and symptomatic thrombocytopenia in the setting of an absent WAS protein on lymphocytes--consistent with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS). This X-linked recessive disorder is caused by a mutation in the gene that encodes the WAS protein (WASp).

Normally, all hematopoietic cells produce WASp (stabilized by WAS/WASL-interacting protein family member 1 gene), which helps organize the cell’s cytoskeleton.



In WAS, leukocytes cannot reorganize the actin cytoskeleton, resulting in impaired immune cell migration and synapse formation. Therefore, patients are at increased risk for recurrent bacterial, viral, and fungal infections. Similarly, the cytoskeleton of platelets is also dysfunctional, resulting in thrombocytopenia. Affected patients have significantly decreased platelet count and size, manifesting with petechiae, purpura, or severe bleeding. Moreover, eczema of variable severity is classically seen. Affected individuals are more prone to developing autoimmune conditions such as idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura or leukemias and lymphomas.




Laboratory investigation demonstrates low to normal IgG, IgM, and high IgA and IgE.  Peripheral blood smear demonstrates thrombocytopenia with small platelets. Flow-cytometry can be used to identify mutated WASp, and a genetic sequence analysis of the WAS gene confirms the diagnosis. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the definitive treatment.



Option Analysis

❌ Antibody class switching:
Incorrect: Antibody class switching defects are usually seen in hyper-IgM syndrome. In addition to severe pyogenic infections, affected patients are susceptible to opportunistic infections with Pneumocystis, Cryptosporidium and CMV. Thrombocytopenia and eczema are not observed in this condition.
❌ Phagosome-lysosome fusion:
Incorrect: A defective lysosomal trafficking regulator gene (LYST) in Chédiak-Higashi syndrome can lead to microtubule dysfunction and imparied phagosome-lysosome fusion. In addition to recurrent infections, progressive neurodegeneration, lymphohistiocytosis and peripheral neuropathy are commonly observed. Pancytopenia (instead of just thrombocytopenia) is a characteristic finding of this condition.
❌ DNA repair:
Incorrect: A DNA repair defect is associated with ataxia-telangiectasia, which presents with a triad of ataxia, spider angiomas, and IgA deficiency. Lymphopenia, rather than thrombocytopenia, is a typical finding.
❌ Hydrogen peroxide production:
Incorrect: A defect in NADPH oxidase in chronic granulomatous disease results in an inability of phagocytes to produce hydrogen peroxide. Abscesses due to catalase positive organisms are classic features. Eczema and thrombocytopenia are atypical.  
✅ Cytoskeletal regulation:
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to her primary pediatrician for evaluation of recurrent infections. In the past year, the patient has had two bouts of lobar pneumonia and several episodes of otitis media. Since birth, she has had multiple skin and soft tissue infections that resolve with oral antibiotics. She was born at 38 weeks gestation to a 28-year-old healthy mother. The patient’s umbilical cord separation was delayed by forty days after birth. She eats and drinks normally and has achieved all developmental milestones. Family history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical exam, a 2 cm x 2 cm well-circumscribed fluctuant lesion is noted. Incision and drainage of this skin lesion expresses a moderate amount of sero-sanguinous fluid. Follow up fluid culture grows Staphylococcus aureus, and flow cytometry studies reveal absence of CD18 antigens on the surface of the patient’s leukocytes.  Which of the following immunoprotective mechanisms is defective based on this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent skin and mucosal infections with absent purulence following incision and drainage of an abscess. These findings, in combination with absence of the CD18 antigen on the leukocyte surface is consistent with leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD), an autosomal recessive disorder. This immunodeficiency results from a defect in CD 18 (LFA-1 integrin)--a cell surface component responsible for leukocyte adherence and transmigration through the endothelium.

This defect results in failure of leukocyte migration and chemotaxis, an increased number of phagocytes  trapped in circulation, and their subsequent inability to invade infected or damaged tissue. Ultimately, this disorder allows pathogens to replicate and spread unchecked by the innate immune system with subsequent tissue damage, an inability to clear cellular debris, and delayed wound healing.

Symptoms of leukocyte adhesion deficiency include recurrent or chronic bacterial or fungal infections of the skin or mucosal membranes (never accompanied by pus or abscess formation), delayed wound healing, poorly formed, thin, bluish scars and delayed umbilical cord sloughing in infants.

Life expectancy without treatment is extremely shortened, with many individuals not surviving past infancy. Diagnosis is based on an elevated number of phagocytes on blood analysis. Flow cytometry can detect absence of expression of the CD18 on the leukocyte membrane. 

Option Analysis

❌ Complement production:
Incorrect: Terminal complement deficiency results from deficiency of C5-C9--a component of the membrane attack complex. A defective membrane attack complex can cause recurrent infections with Neisseria gonorrhoeae or meningitidis. Recurrent pneumonia, otitis media and skin infections are atypical.
❌ Antibody production:
Incorrect: X-linked agammaglobulinemia, an immunodeficiency characterized by a defect in B-cell maturation and severely low immunoglobulin levels, results from a mutation in the BTK gene. Affected patients are susceptible to infections with pyogenic bacteria, enterovirus, and giardia due to paucity of opsonizing and neutralizing antibodies. This disease does not cause peripheral leukocytosis and is inherited in an X-linked pattern; thus it is unlikely to affect a female infant.
❌ Interferon signaling:
Incorrect:  Interferon gamma (INF-ɣ) enhances mycobacterial intracellular killing via formation phagolysosomes. Autosomal recessive deficiency of the INF-ɣ receptor can result in disseminated mycobacterial disease. Recurrent pneumonia, otitis media and skin infections are atypical. Moreover, the CD18 antigen is responsible for leukocyte adhesion to the endothelial cells and would not affect interferon signaling.
❌ Isotype switching:
Incorrect: Isotype switching depends on the interaction of CD40 with its ligand and occurs in naive B cells. The CD18 antigen is responsible for leukocyte adhesion to the endothelial cells.
✅ Leukocyte adhesion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to his primary care physician due to cough and shortness of breath. The patient’s cough is productive of yellow, blood-tinged sputum. The patient has had recurrent pneumonia over the past ten years treated with oral antibiotics. Past medical history is significant for eczema since the newborn period, as well as recurrent pustular and eczematous rashes on the face and scalp throughout childhood. He underwent extraction of his primary teeth at the age of 14 years due to failure of eruption of secondary teeth. Family history is significant for similar symptoms in the patient’s mother. Temperature is 38.7 C (101.7 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 25/min and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates a broad nose, prominent lower lip, deep-set eyes with a prominent forehead, and a rough complexion with exaggerated pore size. Auscultation of lungs demonstrates bilateral rales in the lower lung fields and decreased breath sounds at the right lung base. Which of the following laboratory abnormalities is most likely to be observed in this patient?

choices.text: Elevated levels of serum alpha fetoprotein

questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent pneumonia, an eczematous rash and pustules since childhood, and a history of retained primary teeth in combination with characteristic facies (broad nose, prominent lower lip, deep-set eyes with a prominent forehead)--consistent with hyperimmunoglobulin E syndrome (HIES), also known as Job syndrome. Affected patients usually exhibit elevated serum IgE levels and peripheral eosinophilia.

HIES is a rare primary immunodeficiency disorder that results from defects in a STAT3--a cytoplasmic protein and a component of the JAK-STAT pathway of signal transduction.



Defects in STAT3 result in deficiency of TH17 cells, which normally mediate neutrophil proliferation and chemotaxis at the site of inflammation. Affected patients present in the neonatal period with rash/eczema, impetigo, boils, and recurrent staphylococcal skin abscesses without typical signs of inflammation (“cold abscesses”). In addition, patients often develop recurrent respiratory infections, formation of lung cavities and pneumatoceles. Other features include mucocutaneous candidiasis, characteristic facies (prominent forehead, lower lip, and broad nose), retained primary teeth, and increased susceptibility to malignancies (especially lymphomas) or autoimmune disease. Laboratory analysis usually reveals markedly elevated serum IgE levels and eosinophilia. Diagnosis is based on clinical and laboratory findings in association with a confirmed genetic defect (e.g. STAT3 mutation) via molecular testing.  

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated levels of serum IgE:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Neutropenia:
Incorrect: Although patients with HIES demonstrate intermittent chemotactic defects, they are usually not neutropenic.  
❌ Elevated levels of serum alpha fetoprotein:
Incorrect: Elevated levels of serum alpha fetoprotein are characteristically seen in ataxia telangiectasia, which results from defects in the ATM gene. Affected patients present with cerebellar ataxia, spider angiomas, and IgA deficiency. This patient’s presentation is instead typical of HIES.
❌ Thrombocytopenia:
Incorrect: Thrombocytopenia can be seen in association with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS). Although eczema is common in affected patients, recurrent abscesses and retained primary teeth are atypical.
❌ Abnormal dihydrorhodamine test:
Incorrect: An abnormal dihydrorhodamine test is characteristic of NADPH oxidase deficiency. Affected patients are susceptible to infections by catalase positive organisms including Staphylococcus aureus. An eczematous rash, retained primary teeth, and the characteristic facial features in this patient are atypical.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath and cough. Past medical history includes two episodes of pneumonia, oral thrush, chronic diarrhea and recurrent otitis media. His vaccinations are not up to date due to frequent illnesses. Family history is non-contributory. The patient is at the 2nd percentile for height and weight. Temperature is 38.7 C (101.7 F), pulse is 151/min, respirations are 36/min and blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates white patches in the oral cavity and diffuse rales of the lungs bilaterally. Laboratory results are demonstrated below.

 
 Complete blood count 
 Leukocyte count  8,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  300,000/mm3 
 Lymphocytes  5% 
 CD 19+  low 
 CD 3+  absent 
 Immunoglobulins 
 IgG  220mg/dL 
 IgA  40 mg/dL 
 IgM  15 mg/dL 

Chest X-ray demonstrates bilateral diffuse interstitial infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple findings of immunodeficiency, including oral thrush, recurrent pneumonia, chronic diarrhea and failure to thrive, in combination with absent CD 3+ cells and hypogammaglobulinemia. Together, these findings are indicative of severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome or (SCID). SCID is the most severe form of primary immunodeficiency and may result from an X-linked recessive defect in IL-2R gamma chain (most common) or an autosomal recessive defect resulting in adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency.

The combined absence of humoral and cellular immunity makes affected patients susceptible to any bacterial, viral,  fungal or opportunistic (e.g. Pneumocystis) infection from birth. Additional findings include failure to thrive and chronic diarrhea, as well as absent lymphoid tissue. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates lymphopenia and hypogammaglobulinemia, as well as a decreased concentration of T cell receptor excision circles (TRECs) on polymerase chain reaction. Lymph node biopsy demonstrates hypoplasia of lymphoid tissue with absence of germinal centers. Chest x-ray often shows an absent thymic shadow. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the only curative measure.

Option Analysis

❌ Chronic granulomatous disease:
Incorrect: Chronic granulomatous disease results from a defect in NADPH oxidase and decreased production of reactive oxygen species. Affected patients are susceptible to infections with catalase positive organisms (e.g. Staphylococcus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa). Immunoglobulin levels are usually normal in these patients. Moreover, failure to thrive and chronic diarrhea are atypical.
❌ Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome:
Incorrect: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder that results from a mutation in the WAS gene responsible for cytoskeletal function in leukocytes and platelets. Affected patients present with a triad of recurrent infections, thrombocytopenia, and eczema. This patient’s platelet count is within normal limits, and the patient does not have a history of eczema.
❌ DiGeorge syndrome:
Incorrect: DiGeorge syndrome classically presents with cardiac defects, abnormal facies, and thymic hypoplasia resulting in T-cell deficiency and hypocalcemia. Immunoglobulin levels are within normal limits. Although CD3+ cells are absent in this patient, hypogammaglobulinemia and failure to thrive suggests a combined humoral and cellular immunodeficiency.
✅ Severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ X-linked hyperimmunoglobulin M syndrome:
Incorrect:  X-linked hyperimmunoglobulin M syndrome is often caused by defective CD40 ligand (CD40L) CD4+ helper T-cells. This syndrome is characterized by recurrent pyogenic and opportunistic infections. Laboratory investigations demonstrate high IgM levels and low levels of other immunoglobulins. This patient’s IgM levels are low.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of a large abscess on his right arm. He was treated with oral antibiotics for two similar abscesses over the past year. Previously, these abscesses drained purulent material, and the cultures were positive for Staphylococcus aureus. The patient was hospitalized four months ago with pneumonia and associated empyema. The patient takes no medications and immunizations are up to date.  The patient’s brother died at the age of four months due to infection with Listeria monocytogenes. Temperature is 38.9 C° (102 F°), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 19/min and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates a 4x5 cm fluctuant mass with associated induration and erythema on the right arm. A dihydrorhodamine (DHR) 123 test demonstrates absence of fluorescence on flow cytometry. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s recurrent infections?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with recurrent skin abscesses, a history of empyema and an abnormal DHR test is consistent with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), an X-linked recessive condition caused by NADPH oxidase deficiency. NADPH is a membrane bound protein complex of the phagosome that catalyzes the reduction of O2 to O2-, resulting in oxidative burst and intracellular killing of pathogens.



In CGD, impaired NADPH renders phagocytes unable to effectively phagocytize and lyse microbes--particularly catalase positive microbes.


Affected patients present with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections (e.g., pneumonia, skin and organ abscess and osteomyelitis), as well as bacteremia or fungemia, especially with catalase-positive organisms.


Diagnosis is based on the assessment of neutrophil superoxide production via two modalities:

  •  Nitroblue tetrazolium test (NBT); If neutrophils respiratory burst is working properly, superoxide ions are produced and react with the nitroblue tetrazolium dye, changing its color to a deep blue. 
  • Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) 123 test; If levels of NADPH oxidase are normal, the enzyme will oxidize dihydrorhodamine 123, causing it to fluoresce.

Option Analysis

✅ Impaired oxidative burst:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thymic hypoplasia:
Incorrect: DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.1 deletion) presents with cardiac defects (conotruncal abnormalities [eg, tetralogy of Fallot, truncus arteriosus]), abnormal facies, T-cell deficiency (recurrent viral/ fungal infections), and hypocalcemia due to parathyroid hypoplasia. An abnormal DHR test suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Defective membrane attack complex:
Incorrect: A defective membrane attack complex results in terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9). Affected patients are susceptible to infection with Neisseria sp., rather than Staphylococcus sp. or Listeria sp.
❌ Impaired neutrophil chemotaxis:
Incorrect: Impaired neutrophil chemotaxis results in leukocyte adhesion deficiency. Affected patients present with recurrent skin and mucosal infections without purulence and delayed separation of the umbilical cord.
❌ Cyclic bone marrow suppression:
Incorrect: Cyclic bone marrow suppression presents with cyclic neutropenia. Affected patients present with fever and illness every 2-5 weeks. This condition is typically associated with oral lesions.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of fever, rigors, and shortness of breath. The patient has had three similar episodes in the past without a clear explanation. Family history is significant for the death of a four year old brother due to similar, persistent symptoms. The patient and his family recently emigrated from Honduras. Temperature is 38.7 C (101.7 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 45/min and blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg. Physical examination shows an ill-appearing, lethargic infant. Chest x-ray demonstrates apical infiltrates. Blood cultures grow acid fast bacilli. Impairment of which of the following immunoprotective mechanisms is most likely contributing to this patient’s infection?
questions.solution:
This infant is most likely suffering from a mycobacterial tuberculosis infection of the lungs, with subsequent bacteremia. This presentation is suggestive of interleukin-12 (IL-12) receptor deficiency, an autosomal recessive disorder.

IL-12 is produced by macrophages and mitigates the response to mycobacterial infections via induction of maturation of T-cells into T-helper (Th1) cells, activation of natural killer (NK) cells, and stimulation of TH1 and NK cells to secrete interferon (IFN)-γ.  Released IFN-γ binds its receptors on nearby macrophages followed by subsequent transcription of mediators in the JAK-STAT pathway. This signalling cascade ultimately results in the upregulation of IL-12 receptors, intracellular killing of mycobacteria, and formation of granulomas by tumor necrosis factor-ɑ.



Patients with mutations in IL-12 receptors are unable to secrete IFN-γ, resulting in a reduction in TH-1 response and recurrent disseminated infections in infancy or early in childhood due to typical and atypical mycobacteria. These patients require lifelong treatment with antimycobacterial antibiotics.  

Option Analysis

❌ Complement production:
Incorrect: Terminal complement deficiency (deficiency of complements C5-C9, a component of membrane attack complex) can cause recurrent infections instead with Neisseria gonorrhoeae or meningitidis.
❌ Antibody production:
Incorrect: Bruton agammaglobulinemia is an X-linked recessive disorder that results from a mutation in the BTK gene. Affected patients are susceptible to infections by pyogenic bacteria, enterovirus and Giardia lamblia due to paucity of opsonizing and neutralizing antibodies.
✅ Interferon signaling:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Isotype switching:
Incorrect: Isotype switching is dependent on the interaction of CD40 with its ligand and occurs in naive B cells.
❌ Leukocyte adhesion:
Incorrect: Leukocyte adhesion deficiency results from a defect in CD18--an important component for leukocyte adherence and transmigration through the endothelial walls. The condition presents in infancy with delayed separation of umbilical cord, poor wound healing, and recurrent apustular infections.

questions.text: A 12-month-old boy is brought to his primary care physician for evaluation of oral patches. Review of his medical record indicates a history of recurrent otitis media, pneumonia, chronic diarrhea and failure to thrive. Family history is non-contributory. Physical examination demonstrates a malnourished child, who appears small for his age. Oropharyngeal examination demonstrates scrapable white patches on the tongue but is otherwise unremarkable. Serum electrophoresis reveals low immunoglobulin levels, and a  chest x-ray shows an absent thymic shadow. Deficiency of which of the following enzymes is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient who presents with oral candidiasis, a history of recurrent pneumonia, chronic diarrhea and failure to thrive, in combination with absent thymic shadow on chest x-ray and low immunoglobulin levels, is most likely suffering from severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome (SCID). This severe form of primary immunodeficiency may result from an X-linked recessive defect in IL-2R gamma chain (most common) or an autosomal recessive defect resulting in adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency.

ADA is encoded by a gene on chromosome 20 and removes an amine group from deoxyadenosine triphosphate (dATP), turning it into deoxyinosine monophosphate (dIMP). Deficiency of ADA results in the accumulation of excessive sATP,  which proves toxic to the mitotically active cells--especially lymphocytes. Subsequently, B-cells, T-cells, and natural killer cells decline, with resultant humoral and cellular immunodeficiency. Ultimately, this makes affected patients susceptible to any bacterial, viral, or fungal infections, starting from birth.



Other genetic defects include mutations in autosomal-recessive recombination-activating gene 1 (RAG1), recombination-activating gene 2 (RAG2), as well as genes responsible for cytokine signaling, signaling through the T cell antigen receptor (TCR), TCR and immunoglobulin V(D)J recombination.

Option Analysis

❌ NADPH oxidase:
Incorrect: Deficiency of NADPH oxidase occurs in chronic granulomatous disease, which results in an inability of phagocytes to produce hydrogen peroxide in their lysosomes. Recurrent abscesses from catalase positive organisms are a classic clinical feature. Failure to thrive, chronic diarrhea, and oral thrush are atypical of this condition.
✅ Adenosine deaminase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Xanthine oxidase:
Incorrect: Xanthine oxidase is crucial for purine degradation, as it converts hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid. Deficiency of this enzyme results in abnormally low serum levels of uric acid and subsequent formation of uric acid calculi in the kidney.
❌ Pyruvate kinase:
Incorrect: Deficiency of pyruvate kinase is a common cause of chronic hemolytic anemia.
❌ Myeloperoxidase:
Incorrect: Myeloperoxidase is important for intracellular bacterial killing via catalyzation of hypochlorite from hydrogen peroxide and chloride. Deficiency of this enzyme does present with recurrent Candida infections, but failure to thrive, chronic diarrhea, and recurrent pneumonia are atypical.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl is brought to her pediatricians office for evaluation of shortness of breath and cough. She has had two episodes of pneumonia over the last two years and an episode of bloody diarrhea six months ago requiring hospitalization. Two years ago, the patient was without any significant health complications. Her only past medical history is asthma. Family history is noncontributory. Her immunizations are up to date. Temperature is 38.7 C° (101.7 F°), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Height and weight are currently at the 5th percentile for age. Physical examination reveals faint rales over the right lower lung field. No enlarged lymph nodes are palpated on neck examination. Laboratory results are shown.

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  12  g/dL  
 Leukocyte count  10,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  200,000/mm3 
Immunoglobulins 
IgG  250mg/dL 
 IgA  24 mg/dL 
 IgM  15 mg/dL 
 IgE  undetectable 
 CD4/CD8 ratio  2 (normal, 1-4) 

Chest x-ray reveals a right lower lobe infiltrate. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of recurrent pneumonia and a history of bloody diarrhea, in the setting of hypogammaglobulinemia, which is suggestive of common variable immunodeficiency (CVID).

This disorder results from a defect in B-cell differentiation, impaired lymphocyte activation, and hypogammaglobulinemia. Function of toll-like receptors (TLR) 7 and 9 on both B cells and dendritic cells becomes impaired, which is normally required for B cell activation, cytokine secretion, proliferation, and survival against viral and bacterial DNA, respectively.

CVID typically presents in adolescents (around puberty) or young adults (age 20-40) with recurrent sinopulmonary infections (especially encapsulated bacteria/mycoplasma), chronic respiratory diseases (e.g., asthma and bronchiectasis), gastrointestinal infections (e.g., Campylobacter jejuni, Salmonella or Giardiasis) and failure to thrive. Other commonly reported infections include septic arthritis, meningitis (both bacterial and viral), and bacteremia. Diagnosis is based on decreased serum IgG levels and markedly decreased IgM/IgA in the absence of other defined immunodeficiency states. Lymphocyte and B cell concentrations are typically normal. Treatment includes lifelong intravenous infusion of immunoglobulin. Patients with CVID are at increased risk of associated autoimmune disease and malignancies, regardless of treatment.  

Option Analysis

❌ Severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome:
Incorrect: Severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome is a life-threatening condition that results from mutations that impair B and T cell development and function. It presents in infancy with failure to thrive and severe viral and bacterial infections as maternal immunity wanes. This patient’s T cell count is normal.
❌ Chronic granulomatous disease:
Incorrect: Chronic granulomatous disease results from a defect in NADPH oxidase which leads to  decreased production of reactive oxygen species and respiratory burst. Affected patients are susceptible to infections with catalase positive organisms (e.g. Staphylococcus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa). Immunoglobulin levels are normal in these patients.
❌ DiGeorge syndrome:
Incorrect: DiGeorge syndrome classically presents with cardiac defects (conotruncal abnormalities [eg, tetralogy of Fallot, truncus arteriosus]), abnormal facies, thymic hypoplasia causing T-cell deficiency (recurrent viral/ fungal infections), and hypocalcemia. Immunodeficiency occurs secondary to thymic hypoplasia. Immunoglobulin levels are within normal limits. This patient has normal T cell count and hypogammaglobulinemia.
✅ Common variable immunodeficiency:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Job syndrome:
Incorrect: Job syndrome (autosomal dominant hyper-IgE syndrome) results in impaired recruitment of neutrophils to the site of infection. Affected patients present with cold (noninflamed) staphylococcal abscesses, retained baby teeth, coarse facies, eczema and elevated serum IgE levels (normal levels of other immunoglobulin, unlike this patient).

questions.text: A 10-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. The parents note recurrent upper and lower extremity muscle spasms. He has had no fever, cough, or runny nose. The patient was born full term via an uncomplicated pregnancy and normal vaginal delivery. Family history is unremarkable. Physical examination demonstrates a neonate with rhythmic jerking movements of the upper and lower of extremities bilaterally. The anterior fontanelle is open, pupils are reactive to light, and fundi are normal. Facial examination reveals a small lower jaw, low set ears, and a submucosal cleft palate. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Cardiac auscultation reveals a harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Chest x-ray demonstrates decreased soft tissue attenuation in the right anterior mediastinum. Which of the following immunologic derrangements is most likely to be observed in this patient?

choices.text: Inability to form membrane attack complex

questions.solution:
This neonate’s presentation with generalized tonic-clonic seizures, abnormal facies, muscular spasms and a heart murmur with absent thymic shadow on chest x-ray is most suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome (DGS).

DGS results from a microdeletion on chromosome 22q11.2. This region houses the TBX1 gene, which encodes normal development of the pharyngeal pouches 3 and 4. Normally, the third pharyngeal pouch develops into the thymus and the inferior parathyroid gland, whereas the fourth pouch develops into the superior parathyroid gland.

 


T-lymphocytes are produced in the bone marrow but mature in the thymus, and in patients with thymic hypoplasia, T cells do not mature, resulting in a severely compromised immune system.

The parathyroid gland secretes parathyroid hormone to increase the level of calcium ions in the blood via kidney reabsorption. Thus, parathyroid hypoplasia manifests with hypocalcemia--a known precipitant of seizures and tetany.

In addition, patients with DGS commonly have congenital heart defects (e.g., truncus arteriosus and tetralogy of Fallot), facial abnormalities (cleft palate) and a characteristic “facies” (orbital hypertelorism, short palpebral fissures, short philtrum and bifid uvula). These patients are also subject to higher rates of behavioral and mental health conditions.


Reproduced from Wikipedia

The diagnosis of DGS is based upon reduced numbers of CD3+ T cells, combined with either  characteristic clinical findings or a demonstrated deletion in chromosome 22q11.2 (on fluorescence in situ hybridization). Measurement of serum calcium and parathyroid hormone levels can also be helpful.

Of note, a similar syndrome called velocardiofacial syndrome can also occur with chromosome 22q11.2 deletion and presents with palate (submucous or overt clefts), facial (retrognathia, a long face with a prominent nose), and cardiac defects (ventricular septal defect and right-sided aortic arch).  

Option Analysis

✅ T-cell dysfunction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inability to form membrane attack complex:
Incorrect: Inability to form membrane attack complex (C5-C9) is seen in terminal complement deficiency. This disease presents with recurrent infections with Neisseria gonorrhoeae or meningitidis. Abnormal facies and symptomatic hypocalcemia are atypical.
❌ Insufficient IgA production:
Incorrect: Insufficient IgA production is characteristic of selective IgA deficiency. Most of these patients are asymptomatic; however, some patients develop recurrent sinopulmonary or gastrointestinal infections, atopy, autoimmune diseases and/or anaphylactic blood transfusion reactions. Abnormal facies and symptomatic hypocalcemia are atypical.
❌ Ineffective intracellular killing:
Incorrect: Chronic granulomatous disease is an example of ineffective intracellular killing resulting from a defect in NADPH oxidase and impaired respiratory burst. Affected patients are susceptible to infections with catalase positive organisms. Symptomatic hypocalcemia and thymic hypoplasia are atypical.
❌ Impared immunoglobulin gene rearrangement:
Incorrect: Impaired immunoglobulin gene rearrangement characterizes hyper IgM syndrome. In this disease, B cells produce high amounts of IgM but are unable to produce other immunoglobulins due to a defect in class switching. Affected patients present early in life with opportunistic infections.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room for evaluation of fever, headache, confusion and vomiting for two days. This morning she developed a rash on her lower extremities, prompting her college roommate to bring her to the emergency department. Past medical history includes recurrent pelvic inflammatory disease with Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The patient is sexually active with her boyfriend and uses condoms for contraception. Temperature is 40.2 C° (104.4 F°), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 29/min and blood pressure is 100/55 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates a lethargic female with an erythematous, non-blanching petechial rash on the trunk and lower extremities.  The hips flex when the neck is flexed. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Impaired production of superoxide by phagocytes
Impaired production of the membrane attack complex
Defective adhesion and transmigration of leukocytes
Impaired production of C1 esterase inhibitor

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with meningitis secondary to Neisseria meningitidis. This presentation, in combination with a history of recurrent episodes of Neisseria gonorrhoeae, suggests terminal complement deficiencies (C5-C9) which normally forms the membrane attack complex (MAC).

The complement system helps with three important immune processes: inflammation, phagocytosis, and the creation of MAC.



There are three complement pathways for these purposes:

  •  Classical pathway  
  •  Alternative pathway  
  •  Lectin binding pathway 
All three pathways are initiated by different mechanisms, but terminate with formation of MAC--a protein complex perforates bacterial cell membranes. The function of various components of the complement pathway is demonstrated below.

The deficiencies of complement pathways can be inherited in an autosomal recessive manner or can be acquired secondary to a severe infection or autoimmune conditions. Complement deficiency is divided   into early and late complement deficiency.

Complement deficiencies can also cause hyperactive immune response. For example, C1-inhibitor  normally inhibits the complement system, and its deficiency results in angioedema or non-pitting edema of nondependent areas, due to unregulated activation of kallikrein. C4 levels are characteristically decreased in this condition. Treatment of complement deficiencies include administration of immunosuppressants (in case of overactive immune response) and prophylactic antibiotics (in case of underactive immune response).

Option Analysis

❌ Impaired production of superoxide by phagocytes:
Incorrect: Impaired production of superoxide by phagocytes is seen in chronic granulomatous disease, an immunodeficiency caused by NADPH oxidase deficiency. Affected patients present with recurrent infections with catalase positive organisms. Neisseria is not a catalase positive organism.
❌ Impaired phagosome-lysosome fusion:
Incorrect: Chediak-Higashi syndrome results from a defective LYST gene leading to microtubule dysfunction and imparied phagosome-lysosome fusion. Affected patients present in infancy or early childhood with recurrent infections, progressive neurodegeneration, coagulation defects, silvery hair, lymphohistiocytosis and peripheral neuropathy.
✅ Impaired production of the membrane attack complex:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Defective adhesion and transmigration of leukocytes:
Incorrect: Defective adhesion and transmigration of leukocytes results in leukocyte adhesion deficiency. Affected patients present in infancy or early childhood with recurrent skin and mucosal infections without purulence and delayed separation of the umbilical cord.
❌ Impaired production of C1 esterase inhibitor:
Incorrect: Impaired production of C1 esterase inhibitor causes angioedema or non-pitting edema of nondependent areas due to unregulated activation of kallikrein. Recurrent Neisseria infections are atypical.

questions.text: A 2 year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. The patient has a history of recurrent infections including otitis media, pneumonia, and erysipelas. He recently recovered from a prolonged course of diarrhea due to infection with Giardia. Temperature is 38.7 C° (101.7 F°), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 55/min and blood pressure is 100/50 mmHg. Physical examination shows small bilateral tonsils and rales in the right lower lobe of the lung. The patient is at 25th percentile for height and 10th percentile for weight. Intraepidermal injection of Candida antigens results in the appearance of a large indurated nodule within 48 hours. Flow cytometry of the patient’s peripheral blood smear demonstrates absence of CD19+ cells. Impairment of which of the following immunoprotective mechanisms is most likely contributing to this patient’s disease process?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent bacterial and enteroviral infections in the setting of intact T lymphocyte function and absence of CD19+ B cells (specific B cell surface protein)--suggestive of X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia (XLA).

This X-linked recessive disorder results from a mutation in Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene, manifesting with failure of pre-B cell maturation to mature B cells in the bone marrow. People with XLA lack or have far fewer B cells in peripheral blood and lymphoid tissue, and thus they subsequently lack circulating antibodies of all classes (panhypo-gammaglobinemia). Normal or decreased levels of IgM containing pre-B cells are typically found in the bone marrow.

 


 XLA almost exclusively occurs in males, though the mutation can sometimes develop sporadically rather than being inherited from a parent. Newborns are typically asymptomatic until after 6 months of age, when the mother’s transplacental immunoglobulins diminishes. Without immunoglobulins, children with XLA are at increased risk of viral and parasitic infections (e.g. enterovirus and Giardia lamblia) due to the paucity of opsonizing and neutralizing antibodies. T-cell mediated immunity remains intact, allowing for the clearance of some viral, fungal and protozoal infections. Live attenuated vaccines (e.g. polio vaccine) should be avoided in these patients.

Treatment for XLA includes lifelong intravenous infusion of immunoglobulin as well as prophylactic antibiotics.



Option Analysis

❌ Complement production:
Incorrect: Terminal complement deficiency (deficiency of complements C5-C9) results in an aberrant membrane attack complex--predisposing patients to recurrent infections with Neisseria gonorrhoeae or meningitidis.
✅ Antibody production:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Interferon signaling:
Incorrect:  Interferon gamma (INF-ɣ) is responsible for enhanced mycobacterial intracellular killing via phagolysosomes. Autosomal recessive deficiency of the INF-ɣ receptor can result in disseminated mycobacterial disease in infancy or childhood.
❌ Isotype switching:
Incorrect: Isotype switching is dependent on the interaction of CD40 with its ligand and occurs in naive B cells.
❌ Leukocyte adhesion:
Incorrect: Leukocyte adhesion deficiency results from a defect in CD18, which mediates leukocyte adherence and transmigration through endothelial walls. It presents in infancy with delayed separation of umbilical cord, poor wound healing, and recurrent apustular infections.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to his primary care physician’s office for evaluation of recurrent pulmonary infections and failure to thrive. Since birth, the parents report the patient has had two episodes of pneumococcal pneumonia and five episodes of otitis media. He recently recovered from a diarrheal illness caused by Cryptosporidium parvum. His vaccinations are up to date, and he does not take any medications. Family history is significant for similar symptoms in the patient’s brother, who died from pneumococcal pneumonia last year. Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a child who is small for his age. Laboratory results are shown below.

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  12  g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  10,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  200,000/mm3 
 Immunoglobulins 
 IgG  250 mg/dL 
 IgA  24 mg/dL 
 IgM  700 mg/dL 
 IgE  undetectable 
 CD4/CD8 ratio  2 (normal, 1-4) 

This patient’s condition is most likely caused by a failure of which of the following processes?

choices.text: Recognition of antigens presented on MHC class I
Recognition of antigens presented on MHC class II
Costimulatory signal between B7 and CD28
Costimulatory signal between helper T-cells and CD40
Release of IFN-γ and IL-2 cytokines

questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent pulmonary infections from encapsulated organisms (e.g. S. pneumoniae), opportunistic (Cryptosporidium) infections, and otitis media. In addition, the laboratory findings demonstrate high IgM and low levels of other immunoglobulins, indicating a diagnosis of hyper IgM syndrome. This X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder is most commonly caused by a defective CD40 ligand (CD40L) on CD4+ helper T-cells, which is required for B-cell class switching.

B-cell activation and class switching is a multistep process wherein foreign antigens are endocytosed by B-cells and presented to CD4+ helper T-cells via MHC II on the B-cell surface. Consequently, a costimulatory signal occurs upon binding of the CD40 receptor on B-cells to CD40 ligand (CD40L) on CD4+ helper T-cells. This binding results in the release of cytokines from helper T-cells to induce the B-cell to undergo immunoglobulin class switching. B-cells can then undergo affinity maturation by creating germinal centres within lymph nodes, and they then begin the production of the appropriate antibody to fight off the infection.

This process remains defective in patients with hyper IgM syndrome, and patients are thus prone to recurrent sinopulmonary, pyogenic, and opportunistic infections. Growth retardation can result from high energy expenditure and poor intake during recurrent illnesses. Laboratory findings demonstrate increased IgM and low levels of other immunoglobulins due to this inability for B-cells to undergo class switching.


 

Option Analysis

❌ Recognition of antigens presented on MHC class I:
Incorrect: Recognition of antigens presented on MHC class I is a component of CD8+ cytotoxic T-cell activation. When nucleated cells are infected, the foreign antigen (e.g. viral or cytosolic proteins) is processed in the rough endoplasmic reticulum and loaded onto MHC class I. Later, T-cell receptors on CD8+ cytotoxic T-cell interact with the antigen, leading to its activation and killing of the infected cell. This process is not affected in hyper IgM syndrome.  
❌ Recognition of antigens presented on MHC class II:
Incorrect: Recognition of antigens presented on MHC II is a part of CD4+ helper T-cell activation.  Exogenous antigens (e.g. bacterial proteins) are processed within the endosome and loaded onto MHC class II of antigen presenting cells. This step is followed by an interaction between MHC class II and T-cell receptors on CD4+ helper T-cells, leading to its activation. Helper T-cells then mobilize and recruit other immune cells to fight the infection. This process is not affected in hyper IgM syndrome.
❌ Costimulatory signal between B7 and CD28:
Incorrect: This step is part of T-cell activation, not B-cell activation. T-cells interact with antigen presenting cells via two signals. First, in order for T-cells to be activated, the T-cell receptor has to recognize an antigen presented on the MHC molecule. Second, a costimulatory signal leads to T-cell proliferation and survival via interaction of B7 protein (CD80/86) on dendritic cells and CD28 on naive T-cells. This process is not affected in hyper IgM syndrome.
✅ Costimulatory signal between helper T-cells and CD40:
Correct: See Main explanation.
❌ Release of IFN-γ and IL-2 cytokines:
Incorrect: IFN-γ and IL-2 cytokines are released by helper T-cells in order to recruit macrophages and cytotoxic T-cells to kill phagocytosed microbes. This process is not affected in hyper IgM syndrome.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman comes to an outpatient clinic to evaluate substernal chest pain and pain with swallowing. She immigrated from India six months ago, and this is her first time visiting a physician in the United States. She is sexually active with male and female partners, and she uses condoms inconsistently.Vaccinations are up to date. Temperature is 38.11°C (100.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a frail and cachectic woman. Oral examination reveals white plaques on the buccal mucosa that can easily be scraped away, revealing erythematous mucosa. Microscopic examination of the oral lesions is shown below. Which of the following laboratory findings is most suggestive of this patient's underlying disease process?
 

CDC Public Health Library
questions.solution:
This patient presents with generalized wasting and oral thrush, which is an AIDS-defining illness. In this fully vaccinated individual, the most likely explanation includes both infectious and malignant disease processes. Given her associated history, she likely has an underlying infection with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), which often presents with a low or undetectable CD4 count.
 

Once HIV is acquired, CD4 T lymphocytes are targeted and lysed with a subsequent decline in CD4 count. Most patients are asymptomatic in the weeks immediately after infection; however, some patients may present with an acute flu-like illness (acute retroviral syndrome), including features such as generalized lymphadenopathy, fever, fatigue, and myalgias. During the acute phase, seroconversion (detection of antibodies against the HIV antigen) lags, and most antibody assays will test negative in otherwise positive patients. Next, the window period occurs between the acquisition of HIV infection and seroconversion--P24 antigen tests have to be found to be positive during this period.

Gradually, CD4 T lymphocytes decline coupled with a steady-state plasma viremia. During this latency period, most patients are asymptomatic or have non-specific symptoms, including weight loss, fatigue, persistent generalized lymphadenopathy,, or a maculopapular rash.

If left undetected and treated, HIV infection can progress to AIDS or acute immunodeficiency syndrome in approximately 8-10 years. AIDS is a clinical outcome of HIV infection and is defined clinically as a CD4 count <200 cells/microL or the presence of an AIDS-defining illness. AIDS-defining illnesses include opportunistic infections and malignancies such as esophageal candidiasis, Pneumocystis jirovecii infections, toxoplasmosis, disseminated mycobacterium avium infections, Kaposi’s sarcoma, and Burkitt’s lymphoma, among others.

Notably, the clinical course in neonates (who acquire the infection perinatally) includes nonspecific symptoms such as lymphadenopathy, failure to thrive, and oral thrush. The most common AIDS-defining illnesses in the pediatric population include Pneumocystis jirovecii infection, recurrent bacterial infections, wasting syndrome, candida esophagitis, HIV encephalopathy, and cytomegalovirus. NAT, nucleic acid amplification tests (identification of HIV RNA) are the diagnostic tests of choice in neonates instead of antibody/ antigen-antibody testing performed in adults.  

Option Analysis

✅ Undetectable CD4 count:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hepatitis B core antibodies:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B core antibodies suggest infection with acute hepatitis B. This patient’s vaccinations are up to date, making active hepatitis B infection unlikely.  
❌ Positive heterophile antibody screen:
Incorrect: Infectious mononucleosis is characterized by fever, splenomegaly, pharyngitis, and a positive heterophile antibody test. It does not cause esophagitis or oral thrush.  
❌ Translocation MYC gene (8;14):
Incorrect: Burkitt lymphoma is commonly associated with a translocation involving the MYC gene on chromosome 8 to chromosome 14 upregulated expression. While this is considered an AIDS-defining illness, this patient has no evidence of this disease (the endemic form presents with a rapidly enlarging jaw mass, whereas the sporadic variant presents with an enlarging abdominal mass and ascites).  
❌ HHV-8 Viremia:
Incorrect: Kaposi sarcoma occurs in immunocompromised patients, especially AIDS patients, and is induced by infection with HHV-8. Patients present with multiple cutaneous tumors, which are not present in this patient.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of fever and altered mental status for two days. The patient had a headache for the preceding five days with an episode of vomiting yesterday. Past medical history is significant for an episode of syphilis in his teens, and he did not receive treatment at the time. The patient is sexually active with men and women and uses condoms inconsistently. He does not use intravenous drugs, alcohol, or tobacco. He owns two dogs, a cat, and a parakeet. On initial assessment, the patient appears lethargic, confused, and disoriented to time, place, and person. Temperature is 38.11°C (100.0°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. The patient moves all four limbs to command. Oral examination reveals white, mucosal plaques that cannot be scraped off easily with a tongue depressor. Urine toxicology screening is negative. CD4 count on this visit is 70 cells/microL. The patient undergoes lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals mononuclear pleocytosis and elevated protein. Which of the following findings is most likely to be found on further evaluation of this patient?

choices.text: Multiple ring-enhancing lesions on MRI brain
Crushed ping pong appearance of fungal cell wall under methenamine stain

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, altered mental status, vomiting, oral hairy leukoplakia, significant weight loss, and a CD4 count of less than 100 cells/microL, consistent with AIDS and meningoencephalitis.  In patients with CNS symptoms and severe immunocompromise, (particularly CD4<100 cells/microL) the differential diagnosis should include meningoencephalitis secondary to Toxoplasmosis or Cryptococcosis.

Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii, a parasite that completes a portion of its life cycle in feline feces. Transmission can occur through the consumption of contaminated fruits and vegetables and can result in fulminant infection in those with untreated AIDS and a CD4 count of less than 100 cells/microL. All newly diagnosed HIV patients with CD4 counts less than 100 cells/microL should be screened serologically for toxoplasmosis. Additionally, seronegative patients should be counseled on exposure avoidance and be administered antimicrobial prophylaxis with TMP-SMX  (Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole). Clinical features of toxoplasmosis include meningismus, as well as altered mental status and vomiting. Occasionally, extracerebral manifestations include pneumonitis and chorioretinitis. Fundoscopy will reveal white, cotton-like lesions in a non-vascular distribution. Neuroimaging classically reveals multiple ring-enhancing lesions on an MRI scan. Treatment of choice for active infection includes pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine.
 

Multiple ring-enhancing lesions on an MRI scan; Cerebral Toxoplasmosis
Case courtesy of Assoc Prof Frank Gaillard/Radiopedia.org  
Cryptococcus neoformans is transmitted through respiratory droplets and is present in soil and pigeon droppings, and like toxoplasmosis, presents with features of meningitis in HIV patients with severe immunosuppression (CD4 count<100 cells/microL). Diagnosis is confirmed by the identification of cryptococcal polysaccharide antigen in CSF fluid and cry topical capsular polysaccharide cell walls can be visualized as round encapsulated yeast with India ink preparation. The preferred treatment regime is amphotericin B and flucytosine in the induction phase followed by administration of fluconazole during the consolidation and maintenance phases. Preventive treatment is not recommended for cryptococcus due to the likelihood of adverse effects and drug resistance.
 

India Ink preparation of Cryptococcus neoformans
Wikimedia commons  
Additional complications in patients with CD4 count<100 cells/microL are described below.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Multiple ring-enhancing lesions on MRI brain:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Positive urine Histoplasma antigen:
Incorrect: Disseminated histoplasmosis is characterized by fever, lymphadenopathy, chronic nonproductive cough, hepatosplenomegaly, and transaminitis. CNS symptoms of meningoencephalitis are uncommon.  
❌ Crushed ping pong appearance of fungal cell wall under methenamine stain:
Incorrect: Pneumocystis jiroveci infection is suspected in patients with AIDS and CD4 counts less than 200 cells/microL. Clinical features include an indolent course of a dry cough, fever, dyspnea, and hypoxemic respiratory failure. Neurological symptoms are atypical of Pneumocystis infection.  
❌ Positive IGRA (Interferon-gamma release assay):
Incorrect: All patients with AIDS should be screened for latent tuberculosis with an IGRA assay or a tuberculin skin test as patients infected with HIV are at risk of infection, regardless of the CD4 count. A tuberculoma could present with symptoms indicative of a space-occupying lesion (headache and vomiting). Underlying tuberculosis is unlikely without a history of travel to endemic countries, exposure to tuberculosis, or symptoms suggesting a pulmonary focus.  
❌ Xanthochromia in CSF examination:
