Incorrect: Subarachnoid hemorrhages are described as “thunderclap headaches'' or “the worst headache of one's life”. This patient has features of a space-occupying lesion.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic with skin lesions over his trunk, abdomen, and face. The patient also notes significant weight loss over the last six months. Past medical history is significant for gastroesophageal reflux disease, alcoholic cirrhosis, and esophageal varices. The patient was admitted two months ago for bleeding esophageal varices and underwent endoscopic variceal ligation. The patient is sexually active with men and women and uses condoms inconsistently. The patient uses intravenous drugs, including morphine, and consumes alcohol regularly. Temperature is 36.6°C (98.0°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals anterior and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Oral examination reveals white mucosal plaques that cannot be scraped off easily. Skin lesions on the right arm are depicted below. This patient’s clinical presentation suggests which of the following underlying conditions?
 

Wikimedia Commons
By Unknown author - National Cancer Institute, AV-8500-3620, Public Domain
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of intravenous drug use and unsafe sexual practices presents with elliptical, violaceous papules on the extremities, adenopathy, and weight loss. The above image depicts characteristic lesions of Kaposi sarcoma, which is considered an AIDS-defining illness. Kaposi sarcoma is a cutaneous vascular neoplasm associated with infection by HHV-8 (Human herpesvirus-8). Diagnosis is typically clinical, and lesions may regress with prompt diagnosis and initiation of antiretroviral therapy.

Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome is characterized by severe immunosuppression (CD4 count < 200 cells/microL) or an AIDS-defining illness regardless of the CD4 count, and is typically a consequence of long-standing untreated infection with HIV. AIDS-defining illnesses include opportunistic infections such as Pneumocystis jirovecii, Toxoplasma gondii, Cryptococcus, and Coccidiomycosis. Certain malignancies are also associated with AIDS including Kaposi sarcoma, Burkitt’s lymphoma, CNS primary lymphoma, and invasive cervical cancer.

Option Analysis

✅ Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gastric carcinoma:
Incorrect: Seborrheic keratosis is an epidermal tumor that has a “stuck-on”, velvety appearance. Sudden onset of multiple lesions may indicate occult malignancy.  
❌ Parkinson’s disease:
Incorrect: Severe seborrheic dermatitis is associated with both Parkinson’s disease and HIV. Clinically, it appears as a scaly rash with pruritic, erythematous plaques distributed over the nasolabial folds and scalp.  
❌ Pancreatic cancer:
Incorrect: Dermatomyositis is characterized by Gottron papules (violaceous, scaly lesions over metacarpophalangeal joints) and a heliotrope rash. Malignancies, including adenocarcinomas of the ovary, pancreas, lung, and colon are associated with dermatomyositis.  
❌ Celiac disease:
Incorrect: Dermatitis herpetiformis is characterized by grouped pruritic vesicles and papules on extensor surfaces. It is an extraintestinal manifestation of celiac disease. The violaceous papules seen in this patient are not typical of dermatitis herpetiformis.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man comes to the emergency department with two weeks of dyspnea, fever and a cough productive of blood-tinged sputum. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, HIV, and Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia. The patient is currently compliant with antiretroviral therapy. The patient’s last CD4 count was 450 cells/microL. Current medications include tenofovir-emtricitabine and dolutegravir, atorvastatin, aspirin, and metformin. The patient is sexually active with men and women and uses condoms consistently. The patient does not use intravenous drugs, alcohol, or tobacco. The patient lives in Mississippi in a retirement home and immigrated from India one year ago. Temperature is 38.11°C (100.0°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 130/75 mmHg, SpO2 is 94% on room air. The patient is alert and oriented. Oral examination reveals white, mucosal plaques that cannot be scraped off easily. Physical examination reveals scattered rales on pulmonary auscultation. The patient's chest radiograph is depicted below. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of this patient’s current infectious process?
 

Radiopedia.org

choices.text: Embolization from a deep lower extremity vein
Respiratory infection with a negative sense RNA virus capable of reassortment

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of HIV and CD4 count <500 cells/microL presents with a  two-week history of fever, non-productive cough, and evidence of cavitary lesions in the upper lobes of the lung. These features, in conjunction with a history of travel from a tuberculosis endemic nation, are consistent with reactivation pulmonary tuberculosis. Primary pulmonary tuberculosis involves the formation of a granuloma that walls off the mycobacterial infection from the surrounding tissue. Progressive,  untreated HIV infection leads to a significant decline in CD4 lymphocytes, resulting in reactivation tuberculosis (especially in patients with CD4 counts < 500 cells/microL). Clinical manifestations progressive fever, lymphadenopathy, weight loss, and cough with or without hemoptysis. Chest imaging often demonstrates cavitary lesions in the upper lobes of the lungs.

Patients with CD4 counts of less than 500 cells/microL are likely to develop infections caused by organisms such as Candida albicans (oral thrush), human papillomavirus (squamous cell carcinoma of the anogenital region or cervix), HHV-8 (Kaposi sarcoma: violaceous skin lesions) and Epstein Barr virus (oral hairy leukoplakia).

Patients with underlying HIV infection are also susceptible to typical bacterial pneumonia regardless of CD4 count--including the pathogens Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Staphylococcus aureus. Symptoms are similar to those uninfected HIV patients and include acute onset of fever, pleuritic chest pain, and mucopurulent productive cough. A chest X-ray is most likely to reveal lobar consolidation or diffuse reticulonodular infiltrates.

All patients with HIV infection should be vaccinated against encapsulated organisms including Streptococcus pneumoniae and screened for latent tuberculosis using an interferon-gamma release assay or tuberculin skin testing.  

Option Analysis

✅ Reactivation of a primary infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Colonization by a dimorphic fungus:
Incorrect: Histoplasmosis Is a dimorphic fungus that can result in pulmonary infection, especially in immunocompromised patients. Most patients are asymptomatic or present with fever, fatigue, and cough. It primarily presents in patients with a CD4 count< 150 cells/microL.  
❌ Embolization from a deep lower extremity vein:
Incorrect: Pulmonary embolisms present with acute onset chest pain, dyspnea, hypoxia, and tachycardia--most commonly after precipitating events (e.g. surgery, prolonged immobilization). This patient’s radiograph is suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Respiratory infection with a negative sense RNA virus capable of reassortment:
Incorrect: Patients with HIV infections are at an increased risk of infection with influenza and should be vaccinated against the virus yearly. Clinical symptoms are abrupt and include myalgias, headache, and fever.  
❌ Aspiration of oral flora:
Incorrect: Aspiration of oropharyngeal bacteria results in infection in the dependent areas of the lung, most commonly the right lung since the right bronchus is straighter than the left bronchus. This patient’s radiograph has evidence of upper lobe cavitation.

Two weeks ago, he was initiated on an antiepileptic agent. The patient is sexually active with men and women and uses condoms inconsistently. He uses intravenous drugs, including heroin, and consumes alcohol daily. He has a pet cat at home. Temperature is 38.11°C (100.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals anterior and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. A biopsy of the skin lesion reveals lymphocytic infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Vasculitis following inoculation of a bloodborne pathogen

questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple features consistent with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) with evidence of associated Kaposi sarcoma. HIV is an enveloped RNA virus transmitted via vaginal or anal sexual intercourse, bloodborne exposure (needle sticks, intravenous drug use, blood transfusions), or transmitted from mother to fetus in the perinatal period. Urine, saliva, and tears are considered to carry a low to nearly zero risk of transmission. The presence of concurrent sexually transmitted infections in an exposed individual increases the risk of transmission.

Once exposure occurs, HIV targets dendritic cells, CD4 T lymphocytes, and macrophages. Glycoprotein 120 (gp120) encoded by the viral env gene binds to chemokine receptors present on the surface of T lymphocytes (CXCR4) and macrophages (CCR5). Individuals with a homozygous deletion of the gene coding for CCR5 have relative resistance to HIV infection. Once bound, gp120 undergoes a conformational change that reveals the viral gp41 receptor, allowing membrane fusion with the host cell membrane. Upon viral entry, reverse transcriptase converts the two viral single-stranded RNA molecules to double-stranded DNA and integrates with the host genome using the enzyme integrase.

Polyproteins are transcribed from the newly integrated viral genome, cleaved, and released from the cell using the enzyme protease from the cell. The infected cell eventually undergoes apoptosis, resulting in a decline of CD4 lymphocytes and viremia leading to systemic disease.  

Option Analysis

✅ IV drug use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Exposure to cats:
Incorrect: Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii, a parasite that completes a portion of its life cycle in feline feces. Transmission can occur through consuming contaminated fruits and vegetables and can result in fulminant infection in those with untreated AIDS and a CD4 count of fewer than 100 cells/microL. Infected patients present with features of meningoencephalitis and space-occupying lesions.  
❌ Contact with infected saliva:
Incorrect: HIV is not transmitted through saliva. It is primarily transmitted through bloodborne and sexual contact.  
❌ Vasculitis following inoculation of a bloodborne pathogen:
Incorrect: Hepatitis viruses can be transmitted through blood and manifest with dermatologic findings such as livedo reticularis. This rash appears as reddish-blue skin discoloration, with the legs most often affected. This patient has a different dermatologic finding suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Drug-induced reaction:
Incorrect: Lamotrigine, an antiepileptic agent, can cause Steven-Johnson syndrome. However, the rash is typically tender, ill-defined erythematous macules and is accompanied by fever and epidermal sloughing.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for three days with fatigue, fever, and a sore throat. Past medical history is significant for Chlamydia urethritis as a teenager, and two months ago, he was diagnosed with herpes simplex genitalis. The patient is sexually active with men and women and uses condoms inconsistently. Temperature is 38.11°C (100.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals anterior and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy and a well-circumscribed, oval-shaped maculopapular rash over the abdomen, trunk, and face. Oral examination reveals mucocutaneous ulcers on the tongue, oral mucosa, and palate. Pharyngeal edema and hyperemia are present without exudates or tonsillar enlargement. Abdominal examination is noncontributory. Heterophile antibody screening is negative. Which of the following best describes the most likely microbiological agent responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of sexually transmitted infections, presents with acute onset fever, myalgias, adenopathy (particularly posterior chain), and pharyngitis suggestive of an acute retroviral syndrome. The viral genome of HIV consists of two single strands of positive-sense RNA enclosed within a viral capsid envelope that consists of glycoproteins coded by the env gene. The env gene codes for the glycoprotein gp160, which is subsequently cleaved into gp120 and gp41--allowing for viral entry into cells. Gp120 binds to chemokine receptors on dendritic cells, macrophages (CCR5), and T lymphocytes ( specifically CXCR4). Upon binding to host cell receptors, gp120 undergoes a conformational change that exposes gp41, allowing for the fusion of the viral cell membrane and T cell membrane.

The pol gene codes for reverse transcriptase protein, integrase, and protease. Following viral entry, reverse transcriptase converts the viral genome to ds DNA and is incorporated into the host cell via integrase. The modified genome then gets transcribed into polyproteins cleaved into active proteins by the enzyme protease. The gag gene is the major structural protein of HIV and codes for structural proteins including p24 ( capsid protein) and p7 (nucleocapsid protein).
 
  

Option Analysis

✅ Enveloped, single-stranded, linear RNA virus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gram-positive cocci in chains:
Incorrect: Group A streptococcus causes streptococcal pharyngitis, which presents with tonsillar exudates and swelling. Scarlet fever can occur in the setting of streptococcal pharyngitis and is associated with a sandpaper-like rash. Posterior chain lymphadenopathy and mucocutaneous ulcers are atypical of strep pharyngitis.  
❌ Nonenveloped, double-stranded, linear DNA virus:
Incorrect: Adenovirus can cause pharyngitis with tonsillar exudates and associated adenopathy. Infection with this virus does not cause mucocutaneous ulcers or a diffuse maculopapular rash.  
❌ Enveloped, double-stranded, linear DNA virus:
Incorrect: The Epstein Barr virus and CMV are both enveloped, double-stranded, linear DNA viruses and can cause mononucleosis-like syndrome ( fever, pharyngitis, adenopathy, and splenomegaly). A negative heterophile antibody effectively rules out both EBV and CMV.  
❌ Nonenveloped, single-stranded, linear DNA virus:
Incorrect: Parvovirus is a DNA virus that can cause arthralgias and fever in adults and erythema infectiosum (“slapped cheek”) in children. Mucocutaneous ulcers are not associated with this virus.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of three days of dyspnea, fever, and cough. Past medical history is significant for gastroesophageal reflux disease, dyslipidemia, HIV, and two episodes of Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia. The patient is compliant with antiretroviral therapy and his last CD4 count was 250 cells/microL. Current medications include tenofovir-emtricitabine and dolutegravir, atorvastatin, and aspirin. The patient is sexually active with men and women and uses condoms consistently. The patient does not use intravenous drugs, alcohol, or tobacco. The patient owns two parrots and a cat. Temperature is 38.11°C (100.0°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mmHg, SpO2 is 92% on room air. Physical examination reveals anterior and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy as well as rales over the right anterior and posterior chest. A Chest x-ray is depicted below. Which of the following is the most likely organism implicated in this patient's current clinical condition?
 

Radiopedia.org
questions.solution:
This patient presents with features consistent with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) including fever, productive cough, dyspnea, and a lobar consolidation on chest radiography. In the absence of severe immunosuppression or atypical clinical/ radiographic features, patients with HIV should be treated with typical antibiotics against CAP. Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of CAP, followed by other atypical sp. Including H. Influenzae, which is best covered with ceftriaxone and azithromycin. In addition to typical pathogens, patients with HIV are susceptible to other infective agents secondary to progressive decline in CD4 lymphocytes.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Influenza:
Incorrect: Oseltamivir is recommended for the treatment of influenza, which is characterized by abrupt onset of fever, myalgias, headache, and upper respiratory symptoms. Chest X-ray is often normal, or may show evidence of bilateral, diffuse interstitial infiltrates as opposed to a lobar consolidation.  
❌ Mycobacterium avium complex:
Incorrect: MAC (Mycobacterium avium complex) is a cause of pneumonia in advanced AIDS, especially in those with a CD4 count of less than 50 cells/microL. Clinical features include diarrhea, vague abdominal pain, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and fever. This patient has a CD4 count >200 cells/mcroL.  
❌ Pneumocystis jiroveci:
Incorrect: TMP-SMX is the treatment of choice for Pneumocystis jiroveci infection. Pneumocystis pneumonia is common in HIV-infected patients with a CD4 count< 200 cells/microL and is characterized by progressive dyspnea, dry cough, and diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest radiography.  
❌ Mycobacterium tuberculosis:
Incorrect: Isoniazid, pyrazinamide, ethambutol and rifampin is the treatment regimen for pulmonary tuberculosis. HIV-infected patients are more susceptible to tuberculosis, regardless of CD4 count. Symptoms follow an indolent course of fever, nonproductive cough, and cavitary lesions on chest x-ray.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit for the treatment of pneumonia. He is currently intubated and sedated. Past medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and end-stage renal disease status-post kidney transplant. A biopsy of the lung parenchyma is obtained and demonstrates the findings below. Which of the following organisms most likely cause this patient’s presentation?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of kidney transplant presents with pneumonia and critical illness. A lung biopsy demonstrates owl-eye inclusion bodies, which is typical of infection caused by cytomegalovirus (CMV).  

CMV, or HHV-5, is a type of herpesvirus that results in various clinical manifestations. In otherwise healthy patients, infection by this pathogen is generally asymptomatic. Some patients may develop monospot-negative mononucleosis syndrome, manifesting with symptoms such as fever, myalgia, and sore throat.  

In transplant patients or immunocompromised hosts, CMV infection is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. These individuals are susceptible to CMV pneumonia, and lung biopsy will reveal owl-eye inclusion bodies. Moreover, patients can develop CMV enteritis, encephalitis, and retinitis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Cytomegalovirus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Varicella-Zoster virus:
Incorrect: Varicella-Zoster virus is implicated in the development of chickenpox and shingles. Infection can also result in the development of pneumonia. However, it does not result in owl-eye inclusion bodies.
❌ Epstein-Barr virus:
Incorrect: The Epstein-Barr virus is implicated in the development of mononucleosis, which can present with pharyngitis, fever, lymphadenopathy, and hepato-splenomegaly. However, this pathogen does not typically cause pneumonia.  
❌ Polyomavirus:
Incorrect: Polyomavirus is implicated in developing progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy in patients with HIV. It does not result in owl-eye inclusion bodies.  
❌ Parvovirus  :
Incorrect: Parvovirus typically causes fifths disease in children, which can present as erythema rashes that are most prominent on the cheeks (slapped-cheek appearance). It can also result in an aplastic crisis in patients with sickle cell disease.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of pain with swallowing. The patient reports a burning sensation with swallowing both solids and liquids and noticed white patches in the back of her throat. Two months ago, she was diagnosed with Chlamydia trachomatis and treated with ceftriaxone and oral doxycycline. Past medical history includes IgA nephropathy. The patient is sexually active and uses condoms inconsistently. Temperature is 38.11°C (100.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals anterior and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Lungs are clear on auscultation. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Oral examination reveals dental caries and white posterior pharyngeal mucosal plaques. An external genital examination is noncontributory. She is initiated on oral fluconazole. One month later, she revisits the clinic with worsening dysphagia. An endoscopy is performed, which reveals large, ovoid punched out ulcers throughout the esophagus. Which of the following is most likely to be found on further evaluation?

choices.text: Positive nucleic acid amplification of genital fluid for Chlamydia trachomatis
Herpes simplex virus DNA on PCR assay of genital fluid

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of both candidal esophagitis and herpes simplex esophagitis on endoscopy (punched out ulcers). Both candida and herpes simplex esophagitis are AIDS-defining illnesses--making a diagnosis of HIV and prompt initiation of antiretroviral therapy paramount to prevent further transmission and opportunistic infection(s). The initial diagnostic screening test for HIV consists of an RT-PCR antigen-antibody immunoassay followed by an HIV virologic load for confirmatory diagnosis or negative/indeterminate results.

In acute HIV infection, patients will test positive for antigen-antibody immunoassay with a subsequent negative antibody-only immunoassay and positive virologic load. This occurs because a window period exists between the acquisition of HIV (high viral load) and seroconversion (detection of antibodies against HIV). During this period, immunoassays test for the presence of the p24 antigen, a viral core protein.

If patients with suspected HIV present with a negative antigen-antibody test and negative viral load, the likelihood of underlying HIV infection is low. However, following high-risk exposures such as needle stick injuries, repeat immunoassays can be obtained six weeks and four months after exposure, along with initiation of antiretroviral therapy.

After an initial diagnosis, drug resistance testing is mandated and screening for other sexually transmitted coinfections. Monitoring of both CD4 count and HIV viral load determines both the response to therapy and monitoring for disease progression to AIDS. Monitoring these values helps clinicians to determine when prophylactic antimicrobial therapy should be initiated or if resistance to antiviral therapy arises.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Positive HIV antigen-antibody assay:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cytomegalovirus specific IgM antibodies:
Incorrect: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common cause of esophagitis in immunocompromised patients, however, the esophageal ulcers are typically linear, as opposed to the punched out, vesicular ulcers.  
❌ Positive nucleic acid amplification of genital fluid for Chlamydia trachomatis:
Incorrect: Chlamydia trachomatis can cause urethritis which presents with burning micturition and urethral discharge. It does not cause esophagitis.  
❌ Herpes simplex virus DNA on PCR assay of genital fluid:
Incorrect: Punched-out ulcers are typical of herpes simplex (HSV) esophagitis. Confirmation requires HSV PCR analysis of tissue biopsy from the edge of an ulcer. This patient does not have multiple, painful genital lesions typical of a genital HSV infection.  
❌ Positive heterophile antibody test:
Incorrect: Infectious mononucleosis is characterized by fever, splenomegaly, pharyngitis, and a positive heterophile antibody test. It does not cause esophagitis or oral thrush.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravid woman at 34-weeks of gestation comes to the office for her first visit. She has not had vaginal bleeding or cramping. She immigrated from Ghana six weeks ago and has not had any prenatal care. The patient has a history of intravenous drug use, including heroin. She does not use tobacco or alcohol. The patient had sexual intercourse with an HIV-infected individual one year ago and did not receive post-exposure prophylaxis. The patient’s blood type is AB positive. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals anterior and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Ultrasound confirms a 34-week intrauterine pregnancy. The toxicology screen is negative. After birth, which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic investigation to obtain for suspected neonatal human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)?

choices.text: Nucleic acid amplification test for HIV RNA
No further workup for the mother or fetus

questions.solution:
This patient requires confirmation of her suspected HIV status with a serologic test (PCR antigen-antibody immunoassay) followed by prompt initiation of multidrug antiretroviral therapy if positive to mitigate fetal transmission. In addition, the HIV status of the neonate must be ascertained after birth along with the administration of appropriate post-exposure prophylaxis.

Adults and adolescents are typically screened with anPCR antigen-antibody immunoassay; however, neonates born to HIV-infected mothers are likely to acquire antibodies transplacentally (which persist for several months, making this test unreliable). In neonates, nucleic acid amplification tests (NAT) to detect HIV RNA or DNA are first-line for diagnosis.

Infants born to HIV-infected mothers who did not receive antiretroviral treatment (ART) during pregnancy are considered at higher risk of acquiring HIV than those who received ART. These patients require NAT tests at birth, 2-4 weeks, 4-6 weeks, 8 weeks, and 4-6 months of life. The sensitivity of NAT increases with time and hence several measurements are recommended.  

Option Analysis

✅ Nucleic acid amplification test for HIV RNA:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ HIV antibody-only immunoassay:
Incorrect: HIV antibody and the antigen-antibody immunoassay are unreliable in neonates as maternal antibodies are acquired transplacentally during pregnancy. These antibodies tend to persist until 18 months after birth.  
❌ Anti D immunoglobulin assay:
Incorrect: Anti D immunoglobulin is administered to the unsensitized Rh D mother to prevent alloimmunization and the risk of hemolytic disease of the newborn in subsequent pregnancies. Infants born to Rh-negative mothers are treated with blood transfusions and management of hyperbilirubinemia. The patient, in this case, was Rh-positive.  
❌ HIV Antigen-antibody immunoassay:
Incorrect: HIV antibody and the antigen-antibody immunoassay are unreliable in neonates as maternal antibodies are acquired transplacentally during pregnancy. These antibodies tend to persist until 18 months after birth.  
❌ No further workup for the mother or fetus:
Incorrect: In the absence of prompt diagnosis and treatment, this neonate can develop an HIV infection. Diagnosis and treatment of both the mother and the fetus with postpartum prophylaxis are mandatory.

A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of three weeks of a dry cough, shortness of breath, and fever. The patient has noted significant weight loss (10 lb) over the last nine months. Past medical history is significant for dyslipidemia, HIV, and CMV retinitis. The patient is noncompliant with antiretroviral therapy. Current medications include tenofovir-emtricitabine and dolutegravir and atorvastatin. The patient is sexually active with men and uses condoms inconsistently. The patient does not use intravenous drugs, alcohol, or tobacco. The patient owns two parrots and a cat. Temperature is 38.11°C (100.0°F), pulse is 121/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 98/75 mmHg, SpO2 is 89% on room air. The patient is using accessory muscles of respiration. Physical examination reveals anterior and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Oral examination reveals white, mucosal plaques on the lateral aspect of the tongue that cannot be scraped off with a tongue depressor. Rales are present in the bilateral anterior lung fields. A CT of the patient’s chest is depicted below.  CD4 count is 157 cells/microL. Which of the following organisms is the most likely etiology of this patient’s current disease process?
 

Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of HIV and a CD4 count of less than 200 cells/microL presents with subacute symptoms of fever, hypoxia, and diffuse interstitial infiltrates on CT imaging. Together, these findings are consistent with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, which can be prevented prophylactically via the administration of Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

Pneumocystis jirovecii infection is a common cause of pulmonary infection in HIV infected patients with severe immunosuppression (CD4<200 cells/microL). Clinical manifestations include gradual onset of fever, non-productive cough, progressive dyspnea, tachypnea, and often fulminant respiratory failure. Imaging typically reveals diffuse, bilateral interstitial, or alveolar infiltrates and ground-glass opacities on a CT imaging. Lung biopsy, sputum, or broncholavage samples reveal the cell wall of the fungus which appears as a crushed ping pong ball or a circular ring around a clear center with methenamine silver stain (see image below).
 

P.jirovecii cysts in tissue
Wikimedia commons   
Patients with HIV-AIDS are also susceptible to Histoplasma capsulatum at CD4 counts less than 150 cells/microL. This mycosis is endemic to the Mississippi and Ohio river valleys, and in immunocompetent individuals, Histoplasmosis is unlikely to result in an active infection. In HIV-infected patients, clinical manifestations of disseminated histoplasmosis mimic symptoms of tuberculosis and include insidious onset of fever, weight loss, nonproductive cough, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. Laboratory findings include elevated alkaline phosphatase, LDH, and pancytopenia. Diagnosis is made via detection of urine Histoplasma antigen and the treatment of choice is amphotericin B and itraconazole.

Additional complications that can arise when CD4 counts fall to >200 cells/microL include HIV-associated dementia and progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (reactivation of the JC virus).  HIV-associated dementia accounts for the neurocognitive changes noticed in HIV, once other causes of neurological dysfunction have been ruled out (leukoencephalopathy, infection, neoplasm, infarction). Severe deficits are almost exclusively seen in untreated HIV patients with CD4 counts less than 200 cells/microL and a high viral load. Clinical symptoms include subacute and progressive neurocognitive decline with deficits in memory, concentration, attention, impaired psychomotor speed, and depressive symptoms. Investigations are indicated to exclude alternate conditions including MRI, TSH, vitamin B12, folate levels, and serological testing for syphilis. An MRI scan in HIV-associated dementia typically reveals cerebral atrophy (basal ganglia).

JC virus causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). Immunosuppressed patients including HIV-AIDS patients with CD4 counts less than 200 cells/microL are particularly susceptible to PML. Clinical manifestations include subacute focal neurological deficits such as hemianopia, diplopia, hemiparesis, gait ataxia, or altered mental status. Neuroimaging reveals discrete foci of demyelination in the white matter without mass effect or contrast enhancement.  

Option Analysis

✅ Pneumocystis jiroveci:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mycobacterium avium:
Incorrect: MAC (Mycobacterium avium) infection occurs in HIV infected patients with a CD4 count of fewer than 50 cells/microL. Prophylaxis is best achieved with the administration of a macrolide antibiotic such as azithromycin.  
❌ Cryptococcus neoformans:
Incorrect: Amphotericin B and fluconazole are the treatments of choice for Cryptococcal meningitis. A pulmonary focus is often the source of a CNS infection; however, prophylactic medications are not recommended for this condition. Moreover, this infection is unlikely to occur unless the CD4 count falls below 100 cells/microL.  
❌ Mycoplasma pneumoniae:
Incorrect: Doxycycline can be used to treat Mycoplasma pneumonia which presents with subacute onset non-productive cough and chest radiography with evidence of interstitial infiltrates.  
❌ Cytomegalovirus:
Incorrect: Cytomegalovirus causes retinitis, colitis, and pneumonitis in immunocompromised patients. Prophylaxis of CMV using valganciclovir is not recommended.  Moreover, this infection is unlikely to occur unless the CD4 count falls below 100 cells/microL.

He was adopted at the age of five from India and does not have a history of travel outside the United States. Temperature is 36.6°C (98.0°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Oral examination reveals white, mucosal plaques on the lateral aspect of the tongue that cannot be scraped off. Abdominal examination reveals ascites and hepatosplenomegaly. This patient with a history of untreated HIV, presents with multiple systemic symptoms, ascites lymphadenopathy, and acid-fast bacilli visualized via lymph node biopsy. Given his negative interferon-gamma release assay and this patient's CD4 count, he likely has disseminated mycobacterium avium infection.

Mycobacterium avium is a non-tuberculous bacteria transmitted through inhalation, and patients with CD4 counts less than 50 cells/microL and viral counts >1000 copies/ml are particularly susceptible to symptomatic infection. Disseminated MAC is characterized by fever, weight loss, diffuse lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Laboratory investigations often reveal anaemia, thrombocytopenia, elevated LDH, and elevated alkaline phosphatase levels. Confirmation of the diagnosis is made by isolation of the organism in culture from blood samples or lymph node biopsy specimens. HIV-positive patients on adequate ART do not require prophylaxis with a macrolide-based therapy when CD4 counts fall below 50 cell/microL; however, untreated HIV with immunosuppression below 50 cells/microL requires antimicrobial prophylaxis with either azithromycin or clarithromycin.

Recalling the opportunistic infections with associated CD4 counts and required prophylactic regimen is an appropriate concept for step 1. The table below outlines current CDC recommendations.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Mycobacterium avium infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Latent tuberculosis:
Incorrect: All patients with AIDS, regardless of the CD4 count, should be screened with an IGRA immunoassay or a tuberculin skin test to identify latent tuberculosis. Positive patients should be subsequently treated with isoniazid therapy.  
❌ Toxoplasmosis gondii infection:
Incorrect: Toxoplasmosis is often contracted by consumption of food contaminated with feline feces and presents as a meningoencephalitis with space-occupying lesions in the brain. Active treatment of this condition includes administration of Pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine, whereas prophylaxis is achieved with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole when CD4 counts fall below 100 cells/micro/L.  
❌ Pneumocystis jirovecii infection:
Incorrect: TMP-SMX is the prophylactic therapy recommended for the prevention of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia at CD4 counts less than 200 cells/microL. Infection with Pneumocystis is characterized clinically by hypoxemic respiratory failure.  
❌ Cryptosporidium parvum infection:
Incorrect: Cryptosporidium parvum is an intracellular facultative parasite that can cause chronic diarrhea in immunocompromised hosts. Preventive therapy with nitazoxanide is not recommended.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida at 38 weeks gestation is brought to the delivery room in active labor. The contractions began six hours ago and are occurring every five minutes. The patient does not have leakage of fluid or vaginal bleeding. Fetal movement is normal. The patient was diagnosed with HIV in the first trimester and she has not been compliant with antiretroviral therapy or her prenatal visits. The uterus is soft and nontender between contractions. The fetal heart rate tracing shows accelerations with variability and does not show decelerations. The cervix is 6 cm dilated, 100% effaced and the fetal vertex is at +1 station. The amniotic sac is tense and palpable and has not ruptured. Maternal HIV viral load is 750 cells/ml. The patient delivers the infant who is subsequently initiated on zidovudine. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this medication?

choices.text: Selective inhibition of HIV reverse transcriptase

questions.solution:
This patient with untreated HIV and a high viral load presents in active labor and carries a high risk of vertical transmission to the fetus. Ideally, delivery via cesarean section should be pursued to mitigate any risks of vertical transmission followed by administration of a multi-drug antiviral regimen to the baby.

Antiretroviral therapy should be administered to all HIV-positive pregnant patients, regardless of the CD4 count or viral load to mitigate the risk of vertical transmission and treat the maternal infection.  The regimen of choice in pregnant patients with HIV includes a dual NRTI with a protease inhibitor or an integrase inhibitor such as tenofovir disoproxil fumarate-emtricitabine with dolutegravir. Earlier initiation of treatment can reduce the risk of transmission and can improve chances of viral suppression at term.

Cesarean delivery is indicated in HIV-positive patients if the viral load at the time of delivery is more than 1000 copies/mL. Intrapartum zidovudine along with the continuation of an ART regimen is indicated for patients who have viral loads >1000 copies/ml at the time of delivery. Operative vaginal delivery, intrapartum scalp monitoring, and artificial rupture of membranes should be avoided.

Post-exposure prophylaxis with multidrug ART is indicated for all neonates born to HIV-infected mothers (viral load>1000 cells/mL) and should be initiated within 6-12 hours of birth. Neonates born to mothers with viral loads <50 cells/mL (low risk) can receive zidovudine for 4 weeks as antiretroviral therapy. In resource-rich settings such as the United States, breastfeeding is contraindicated in neonates born to HIV-positive patients, as transmission can occur despite adequate viral suppression.

Option Analysis

✅ Selective inhibition of HIV reverse transcriptase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ HIV Integrase inhibition:
Incorrect: Medications such as bictegavir, dolutegravir, elvitegravir, and raltegravir are characterized by inhibition of intengrase.  
❌ HIV protease inhibition:
Incorrect: Medications including atazanavir, darunavir, and ritonavir are characterized by protease inhibition.  
❌ Viral entry inhibition:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide and maraviroc are characterized as HIV viral entry inhibitors.  
❌ Inhibition of the 50s ribosomal subunit:
Incorrect: This stem describes the mechanism of action of macrolide antibiotics, which are not a component of acute HIV therapy or prophylaxis.

Epigastric pain radiating towards the back
Increased dorsocervical and abdominal adipose tissue

questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with HIV infection and initiated on a medication that prevents the virus from cleaving the Gag-Pol polyprotein. Laboratory results are notable for hyperglycemia and hyperlipidemia. As a result, this patient was likely started on a protease inhibitor, which can lead to lipodystrophy.

Protease inhibitors bind and inhibit HIV-1 protease, thereby preventing the virus from processing the Gag-Pol polyprotein into its functional parts and thus impeding viral replication. Protease inhibitors are generally used with other medications as part of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART).

A common side effect of protease inhibitors is metabolic disorders, such as insulin resistance, hyperglycemia, and hyperlipidemia. These metabolic disorders are often followed by lipodystrophy. Lipodystrophy is characterized by abnormal accumulation of fat tissue in the abdomen, breasts (in women), and around the cervical vertebrae and loss of fat in the extremities and face. As a result, affected patients will classically have thin extremities, emaciated-appearing faces, and truncal obesity. Some studies have reported the incidence of lipodystrophy to be over 50% in patients taking protease inhibitors.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Reduced pinprick sensation in the bilateral upper extremities:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes peripheral neuropathy associated with nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) such as lamivudine stavudine and didanosine. Although NRTIs can cause hyperglycemia and hyperlipidemia as side effects, these medications function by inhibiting viral reverse transcriptase, not by inhibiting viral cleavage of the Gag-Pol polyprotein. In contrast, peripheral neuropathy in protease inhibitor use is rare.  
❌ Unilateral calf erythema and swelling:
Incorrect: A deep vein thrombosis (DVT) can manifest with unilateral calf erythema, swelling, and pain. However, the incidence of DVT or pulmonary embolism after initiating protease inhibitor therapy is infrequent, with some studies reporting the incidence rate to be less than 2%. In contrast, this patient already has laboratory findings suggestive of metabolic disorder (e.g., hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia) and is at a far greater risk of developing lipodystrophy secondary to protease inhibitor use.  
❌ Epigastric pain radiating towards the back:
Incorrect: Certain nucleotide/nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) can cause pancreatitis, which classically manifests with epigastric pain radiating to the back. In contrast, the instance of pancreatitis following protease inhibitor therapy is rare. Furthermore, although this patient has hypertriglyceridemia, triglyceride levels exceeding 1000 mg/dL are generally required to increase an individual’s risk of developing pancreatitis significantly.  
✅ Increased dorsocervical and abdominal adipose tissue:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blistering and desquamation of the skin and mucous membranes:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), which affects less than 30% of the total skin surface and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), which affects more than 30% of the total skin surface. Patients on non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) therapy are at risk of developing SJS/TEN. In contrast, this patient was initiated on a protease inhibitor, which has a higher likelihood of causing metabolic syndrome and lipodystrophy than SJS/TEN.

This patient presents with abdominal pain radiating towards the groin, nausea, vomiting, and hematuria on urinalysis. She likely has nephrolithiasis. Among the medications listed to treat HIV infection, indinavir is most strongly associated with nephrolithiasis.

Indinavir is a protease inhibitor. It binds and inhibits HIV-1 protease, thereby preventing the virus from processing Gag-Pol polyproteins into its functional parts and thus impeding viral replication.

As with other protease inhibitors, indinavir can cause gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, nausea, vomiting), metabolic disorders (e.g., hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia), and lipodystrophy. Furthermore, patients on indinavir may develop nephrolithiasis and associated hematuria. Nephrolithiasis occurs since around 20% of the drug molecules are renally excreted and may subsequently aggregate to form stones. Therefore, individuals treated with indinavir should maintain good hydration to reduce the risk of nephrolithiasis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acyclovir:
Incorrect: Acyclovir is a guanosine analog that inhibits viral DNA polymerase. The medication can treat infection by the herpes simplex virus (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus (VZV). Although acyclovir can cause crystalline nephropathy and nephrolithiasis, this patient has no indications warranting acyclovir treatment. As a result, it is unlikely that acyclovir is responsible for the patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Zidovudine:
Incorrect: Zidovudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used to treat HIV infection. The medication can cause side effects, including anemia, leukopenia, lactic acidosis, and lipodystrophy. However, the medication is not typically associated with nephrolithiasis.  
✅ Indinavir:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Efavirenz:
Incorrect: Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) used to treat HIV infection. It can cause side effects, including hepatotoxicity, hypersensitivity rash, and vivid dreams. However, the medication is not typically associated with nephrolithiasis.  
❌ Ritonavir:
Incorrect: Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor that prevents HIV from cleaving the Gag-Pol protein into its functional parts, hindering viral replication. The various protease inhibitors can cause hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, and lipodystrophy as side effects. Nephrolithiasis, in contrast, tends to be more strongly associated with the protease inhibitor indinavir.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of fever, fatigue, and sore throat, which have been ongoing for 2 weeks. He thinks he may have “mono.” The patient has had sexual intercourse with three partners over the past year and has been using condoms inconsistently. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), blood pressure is 110/85 mmHg, and pulse is 73/min. Physical examination reveals cervical and supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. The tonsils are erythematous but normal in size. An HIV PCR test is positive for HIV-1. The patient is started on an antiretroviral regimen of emtricitabine, tenofovir, and dolutegravir. What is the mechanism of action by which dolutegravir acts as an HIV medication?
questions.solution:
This patient is started on dolutegravir, which works as an integrase inhibitor.  

Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is initiated at the diagnosis of HIV infection. It typically consists of a 3-drug regimen, consisting of 2 nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and an integrase inhibitor.  

Integrase inhibitors, as the name suggests, reversibly inhibits HIV integrase, thereby blocking the integration of the HIV genome into host cell chromosomes. These medications are recognized by the presence of “tegra” within their name (e.g., bictegravir, dolutegravir, elvitegravir, raltegravir).    

Common side effects associated with integrase inhibitor therapy include nausea, headache, and myopathy with an increased creatine kinase level. 

Option Analysis

❌ Protease inhibitor:
Incorrect: Protease inhibitors include medications ending in “-navir”, such as atazanavir, indinavir, lopinavir, ritonavir, and saquinavir. By blocking viral protease, these agents are able to prevent HIV mRNA cleavage and the maturation of new viruses. They are associated with hyperglycemia, gastrointestinal intolerance, and lipodystrophy.    
✅ Integrase inhibitor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Entry inhibitor:
Incorrect: Entry inhibitors include enfuvirtide and maraviroc. Enfurvitide binds viral gp41 whereas maraviroc binds CCR-5 on T-cells/monocytes. In contrast, dolutegravir works as an integrase inhibitor.   
❌ Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor:
Incorrect: Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) are a mainstay of HIV treatment. They competitively inhibit nucleotides from binding to reverse transcriptase, thereby terminating DNA chain elongation. Examples of NRTIs include abacavir, didanosine, emtricitabine, lamivudine, stavudine, tenofovir, and zidovudine.  
❌ Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor:
Incorrect: Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs) include delavirdine, efavirenz, and nevirapine. These medications allosterically inhibit reverse transcriptase, thereby terminating DNA chain elongation. In contrast, dolutegravir works as an integrase inhibitor.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the clinic with a history of fatigue and a sore throat that began three days ago. The patient denies pain in swallowing, cough, dyspnea, or chest pain. Past medical history is significant for gonococcal urethritis in his youth. The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease and IgA nephropathy. The patient is sexually active with men and women and uses condoms inconsistently. Temperature is 38.11°C (100.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals anterior and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Oral examination reveals mucocutaneous ulcers on the tongue, oral mucosa and palate, and white mucosal plaques. Pharyngeal edema and hyperemia are present without exudates or tonsillar enlargement. Abdominal examination is noncontributory. Heterophile antibodies are negative. He is found to be HIV-2 positive with a CD4 count of 500 cells/microL. The patient is initiated on therapy with an integrase inhibitor. Which of the following therapies was most likely provided?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with newly diagnosed HIV-AIDS. The most appropriate treatment regimen given his findings should include a therapeutic regimen containing integrase inhibitors such as dolutegravir, raltegravir, or elvitegravir.

Once a diagnosis of HIV is made via an HIV antibody-antigen immunoassay, this is followed by an antibody test to differentiate between HIV-1 and HIV-2. HIV-1 is considered a more pathogenic variant with rapidly rising viremia and progressive decline in CD4 counts, whereas HIV-2  results in a slower decline in CD4 count. In addition, HIV genotyping should occur, to examine for potential mutations and resistance to various antiviral regimens.

Initiation of antiretroviral therapy is recommended at the time of diagnosis to promote viral RNA suppression, reduce the risk of transmission, and improve cellular immunity (CD4 count).Typically, patients with a new diagnosis of HIV and a detectable viral load should be initiated on antiretroviral therapy. Patients with susceptibility to opportunistic infections (AIDS with a CD4 count< 200 cells/microL) should also be initiated on appropriate antimicrobial prophylaxis.

Recommended treatment regimens typically consist of two nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors and one integrase inhibitor (e.g. dolutegravir plus tenofovir alafenamide- emtricitabine). Past medical history and medication history should be taken into consideration when choosing an appropriate treatment regimen as well. For example, patients with a history of chronic renal disease (eGFR<60 mL/min/1.73m2) and osteoporosis should avoid regimens with tenofovir.  

Option Analysis

✅ Dolutegravir:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole:
Incorrect: TMP-SMX is the ideal agent for antimicrobial prophylaxis against Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia, an opportunistic infection that can develop in patients with AIDS ( CD4<200 cells/microL). In this case of newly diagnosed HIV infection, TMP-SMX prophylaxis is not recommended.  
❌ Tenofovir:
Incorrect: Therapeutic antiretroviral regimens including tenofovir should be avoided in patients with a history of chronic kidney disease as it is nephrotoxic. Moreover, this medication is a reverse transcriptase inhibitor.  
❌ Azithromycin:
Incorrect: Azithromycin is used for the prophylaxis of Mycobacterium avium complex infections in AIDS patients when the CD4 counts <50 cells/microL. In this case of newly diagnosed HIV infection and a CD4 count of 500 cells/microL, TMP-SMX prophylaxis is not recommended.  
❌ Caspofungin:
Incorrect: Caspofungin is an echinocandin used in the treatment of esophageal candidiasis. Although this patient has symptoms indicating oral thrush, he does not have symptoms suggestive of esophagitis (odynophagia) and hence, caspofungin is not recommended.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to an outpatient clinic for HIV follow-up. He has been feeling well and is asymptomatic. The patient has been compliant with his treatment regimen of bictegravir, tenofovir alafenamide, and emtricitabine; however, he continues to have an elevated HIV-1 viral load. The patient is prescribed maraviroc in addition to continuing the current highly active antiretroviral therapy regimen. What is the mechanism of action of this new medication?

choices.text: Inhibiting nucleotide binding to reverse transcriptase

questions.solution:
This patient is started on maraviroc, which works by binding to T-cell and monocyte CCR-5 receptors and preventing viral entry.  

Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is initiated at diagnosis of HIV infection. It typically consists of a 3-drug regimen, consisting of 2 nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and an integrase inhibitor, to prevent resistance. There are newer classes of HIV medication that have been developed to address treatment-resistant strains of HIV.    

Entry inhibitors, also known as fusion inhibitors, are examples of such drugs. These medications are given to patients who show replication of HIV despite ongoing ART.    

In particular, maraviroc is an HIV medication that acts as an entry inhibitor by binding CCR-5 on the surface of T-cells and monocytes thereby blocking the interaction with gp120. It cannot be used against HIV strains that bind to CXCR4 and is thus used only as an add-on medication to HAART. Its main side effects include diarrhea, joint and muscle pain, jaundice, and transaminitis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Binding to CCR-5:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Binding to gp41:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of enfuvirtide. It is an injectable HIV medication that acts by binding to the viral gp41 protein and preventing viral entry into host cells. Unlike other HIV medications, which are active against HIV-1 and HIV-2, enfuvirtide is only active against HIV-1.   
❌ Inhibiting HIV integrase:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of integrase inhibitors. These medications block integration of the HIV genome into host cell chromosomes through reversible inhibition of HIV integrase. Common side effects include nausea, headache, as well as myopathy with an increased creatine kinase level.  
❌ Inhibiting HIV protease:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of protease inhibitors. By blocking viral protease, these medications are able to prevent HIV mRNA cleavage and the maturation of new viruses.   
❌ Inhibiting nucleotide binding to reverse transcriptase:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs). In contrast, maraviroc works by binding to CCR-5 on the surface of leukocytes and preventing it from interacting with viral gp120.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to his outpatient provider to evaluate fatigue and lymphadenopathy. He states the symptoms have been ongoing for two weeks. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and has been sexually active with multiple female partners. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), blood pressure is 115/73 mmHg, and pulse is 78/min. Physical examination reveals enlargement of cervical, supraclavicular, and inguinal lymph nodes. The tonsils appear erythematous, but no exudate is present. Subsequent testing reveals the presence of p24 antigens and anti-HIV antibodies. The patient is started on several antiviral drugs, one of which may cause side effects, including fat redistribution, hyperlipidemia, and hyperglycemia. Which of the following viral proteins is most likely targeted by this drug?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with lymphadenopathy, fatigue, fever, and sore throat. Laboratory testing reveals the presence of HIV antigens and anti-HIV antibodies. The patient was likely started on a protease inhibitor as part of her treatment regimen.

Protease inhibitors (e.g., darunavir, indinavir, ritonavir) can be used to treat HIV infection. These medications bind and inhibit HIV-1 protease, thereby preventing the virus from processing the Gag-Pol polyproteins into its functional parts and thus impeding viral replication. Protease inhibitors are rarely used alone since HIV quickly develops resistance via point mutations of the pol gene, which is the gene that encodes HIV-1 protease. Typically, protease inhibitors are used as a part of the highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) combined with other drugs.

The most common side effects of protease inhibitors include gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, nausea, vomiting) and metabolic disorders (e.g., hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia). These metabolic disorders are often followed by lipodystrophy. Lipodystrophy is characterized by abnormal accumulation of fat tissue in the abdomen, breasts (in women), and over the cervical vertebrae and loss of fat in the extremities and face.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Nonstructural protein 5A:
Incorrect: Nonstructural protein 5A (NS5A) is found in the hepatitis C virus (HCV) and assists with viral RNA replication. This protein is targeted by medications such as ledipasvir, elbasvir, and daclatasvir. In contrast, these medications would be ineffective in treating infection by HIV, which lacks the NS5A protein.  
✅ Protease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Integrase:
Incorrect: Integrase inhibitors (e.g., raltegravir, dolutegravir) prevent viral DNA from integrating with the host’s DNA, impairing viral replication. These medications can cause elevated creatinine kinase, myopathy, and insomnia as side effects. However, integrase inhibitors would not typically cause fat redistribution, hyperglycemia, or hyperlipidemia.  
❌ Glycoprotein 41:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide is a fusion inhibitor that binds viral glycoprotein 41 (gp41) and prevents the virus from fusing with CD4 T-cells. Enfuvirtide may lead to injection site reactions but would not cause fat redistribution, hyperglycemia, or hyperlipidemia.  
❌ DNA polymerase:
Incorrect: A wide variety of antivirals, such as cidofovir, foscarnet, and acyclovir, work by inhibiting viral DNA polymerase and preventing viral replication. However, HIV does not have a DNA polymerase. As a result, these medications would be ineffective in treating HIV infection.
